After a decision to cut cable, YT is our family's primary video media source.  I'm not one to "smash" a like button, comment down below, or "subscribe" to anything for that matter.  But after following you down the proverbial rabbit hole for the last few hours, I just wanted to say that I think, and feel, that you are a good person.  I can hear it in your voice, even when reading the composition of household dust.  I can see it in your eyes, the wonder, the excitement, the way you look at your wife and children. The way others carry themselves around you shows a lot, they gravitate to you.  You can make some very uncomfortable subjects and situations, seem an opportunity and adventurous.  Your choices for subject matter are smart and creative, your presentation effective and precise, and the results are well deserved. You truly fill a niche spot without any of the dry, condescending, or socially awkward aspects that accompany most others presenting this type of subject matter.  I wanted to thank you for being inspirational to not only a 51-year old man, but to his teen and pre-teen sons.  I just subscribed, so please keep up your exciting and educational work, my hope is that it rewards and fulfills you.

It's funny that we have a similar life story. I did my bachelor in Physics and got lost studying Environmental Science for my Master degree in Perth  (What did I think at that time, poor me). I got lost in teaching environmental science for about 6 years after master graduation but wasn't happy at all doing it (sorry my then dear students). In total I've spent 10 years of my life doing stuff outside of physics and this doesn't make me happy at all. I applied for scholarship and got it to do PhD in Environmental Soil Physics at the University of Sydney. I just started 3 months but found myself unhappy doing it because my passion is filmmaking and physics education. I don't wanna be a scientist but I wanna incorporate filmmaking and physics education. I produced 2 short movies and both won Indonesian short movie national competition 2 years consecutively. So, now I'm in the process of transferring to physics education for my PhD and will start soon in July 2022. I've been making some vlogs around Sydney but don't have the courage yet to make videos related to physics education. I go to YouTube to find inspiration and found you. Voila, What a coincidence!!!! Never knew, never watched, never be informed about you before!!! I'm so inspired by you. I hope that I will be able to achieve success as you do. The thing I found is that now I feel so much more happier inside because I get to do what I love the most in life. I'll be spending 3.5 years doing my PhD in physics education and I'm studying the whole day and night now to find my true self about what I really want to produce. I'm 35yo and feel empowered than ever to start a new chapter of my life and going back to my real calling in life. Wish me luck!!!! I thank you so much.

NEWS ALERT: Despite Derek Muller's disclaimer that he "made up" Veritasium, element i is, in fact, a 9.64 yottahertz gamma-ray. If anti-hydrogen had an atomic number, it would be -1. When matter encounters equivalent antimatter, it converts into uncharged photons, meaning photons are "halfway" between matter and antimatter. Photons thus have an atomic number halfway between 1 and -1, which mathematically is the imaginary unit i, the symbol for Veritasium. Finally, a photon with 42.0 atomic units of energy is an extreme gamma-ray. Thus the identity of Veritasium is uncovered: It is a gamma-ray with a frequency of 9.64 yottahertz.

This kind of format is good. But I notice that even when I post alot anywhere, I get completely ignored. In places we are permitted, such as online forums, the ones that are available 'freely' tend to demand extensively undeserved or unearned relative respect such that we get censored (and censured) when or where we dare to speak against conventional views. There's so much science stuff on YouTube, that's factually inaccurate. What's great about your content, is it's accuracy (Veritas), and you communicate sometimes complex stuff simply, I admire the animations. I'm an engineer, who is also a scientist. As an engineer, and chemist, working for a scientific instruments company, I was tasked with running training courses for customers. The customers sometimes had no scientific background, and some had PhDs. I had to find a way of communicating the content, across a broad spectrum of intellect. I think I did OK. And I think you are doing much the same, and doing a wonderful job. Science is wonderful, once you understand some of it and start asking questions. But so many people don't, because it isn't communicated well, and the chance to "hook" people into the scientific field is so often missed. Well done you.  I think you might be contributing more to getting more people involved in science than you might think.

Understanding Survivors bias shouldn't send you directly to dismissal, but to game theory.

What are the likelyhoods of the different outcomes. What are the costs and benefits of said outcomes. Is the payoff of the low propability ultimate succes so big, the endeavour is worthwhile?

A one in a million chance to win a billion dollars, is a good deal, if you have to put up a dollar. If you have to put up 10K dollars, then it's not. Unless you think you get 9K dollars worth of fun (or PR, or anguish of your rivals, or attraction to the prefered sex, etc) out of it.

A camera cannot "record everything exactly as it happens". Certainly, within some limit, it appears to replicate the things placed before it while it is working. In reality, a digital camera can only create a two dimensional representation of the light it receives after it passes through an aperture at least, but often also through a lens or series of lenses--which can and often does distort the light and resultant image, a fact photographers and cinematographers frequently manipulate to their advantage to achieve certain effects (lensing and lens distortions are a well known 'artefact' of optical technologies like telescopes and camera lenses).

Not only is the resultant image only a two dimensional representation of the light, but it is also only a two dimensional representation of certain wavelengths and frequencies of light that have a minimum amount of energy that can be detected by the CMOS. Celluloid films, like traditional 35mm film or 8mm film, are technically three dimensional but only as a result of the required light sensitive chemical emulsion and it is not capable of capturing and reproducing a two dimensional representation. Film, digital CCD, and digital CMOS sensors are still physically limited to a narrow range of EMF.

So, for these reasons and more, I always balk at statements like camera's "record everything exactly as it happens" because they literally don't and cannot.

Where to go - isn't that always the question.  And you have answered that many times.  Thank you.  I started watching your videos for my inner science geek.  And I love that you are now at a reflective point in your life which includes a family and grey in the beard.  I can relate, even though my boy now has a beard of his own & my daughter has a husband of her own.  I want to mention a few things in relation to the direction I'd like to see you go.  I think of the podcast of Steven Levitt (people I mostly admire) he did with Ken Jennings and what was discussed in terms of education.  How the pandemic has helped push learning like what you provide on Veritasium forward.  And what really good teachers provide.  I also think of a Dr. Zac Bush - many of his videos with the Global Health Education Summit are too long, lack charts, resources within the video that help you follow along.  They make me think of listening to a sermon or a lecture.  Neither of which I care to hear very often, but I think he might have some good information in terms of where the world should maybe head (which I think I could summarize as anti-chemical, anti-disease focus).  So I am not saying that Dr. Bush is 100% correct in any way, but if you think someone like that could merit your help in terms of presentation - then maybe that could be a direction for you.  Also last night I watched a show I think on PBS about music photography.  And they debated the analog to digital change, and how instant & abundant pictures have become.  So what if what you post/upload in terms of new content takes longer?  Scarcity is a good thing for the value of demand! I have an idea MAYBE ... I'm also an engineer with a masters in aerospace engineering. I also have a desire to change over to something from the arts (I am trying to write a scifi novel). As an engineer, I look for patterns (formulas ... if you will). So my "idea" (and something I've always wondered) ... is there a formula or pattern for writing a novel? I know this might not fit into what you typically do but let me explain. I was never that good at writing but I took a course on writing and noticed a pattern for how each type of writing was done. Very interesting auto-biography, but it leaves two questions unanswered:
1. Why is 'Veritasium' supposedly element 42? (which in reality is Molybdenum).
2. What is your actual name?

Actually, question 2 is easily answered by searching on Google for 'Veritasium'. It turns out you're almost exactly a year younger than my son (whose name is also Derek). I also have a daughter, 5 years older than Derek, named Hermione. She was born in Australia (Melbourne), since that's where my wife and I lived at the time. Derek was born in Guildford, Surrey England, which is close to where we lived as a family then. Son is now married and lives in Bosham (pron 'Bozzam'), near Chichester West Sussex. He and his Swedish wife have three grandchildren (my grandchildren, not theirs), aged 7, 4 and getting on for 1.

My family (parents, brother and self) emigrated from England to Melbourne when I was 9, another brother was born there. I grew up there and married the daughter of German immigrants (she was born in Wolfsburg, home of Volkswagen, for whom her ex-Luftwaffe father worked, post WW2). I emigrated back to England at age 31 with wife and infant daughter. My grandchildren have an interesting mixture of ancestry.

I made a career in electronic design, which in more recent years has involved low-level programming of embedded systems, for which I design the electronics. I qualified in electronic engineering at RMIT in Melbourne in 1970s. In 1990s, I graduated (BSc (hons 1) from the Open University in the UK, partly to enhance my academic experience in fields connected with my career, and partly to show that I could still do it.

Anyway as a fellow engineer, it's been great to meet you! All the best for your future career.

Graduated, just barely, in four years from the 3rd ranked ChemE department in the country. Actually we started with 70 Chem E. Freshmen, but only graduated 28 (that’s me #28) but since we started with 70, I enjoy telling people that I graduated in the top half of my class. Spent about a year doing ChemE related work then started straying afield into market research, strategic planning then into marketing in the healthcare industry. The big jump was from marketing for Revlon division to an ad agency. Having always enjoyed creative hobbies, painting, photography, music… I tended to enjoy my time more with creative departments and less my original area in client services. We’ll, after two years I was lucky enough to be named Creative VP and get to spend my time with the artists and writers at the agency working on print and even getting to direct TV commercials.

That was my best job, but when you have about 20 important clients each of whom think they deserve of your time, we’ll, I burnt out. After that I had a couple of consulting companies, worked with some hi-tech startups, but never again achieved the fun or financial success of working with ‘creatives’ in advertising.

I’m now retired with some healthcare problems, and now my greatest enjoyment comes from learning. My areas of interest have become physics, quantum theory (one of the subjects in high school that lead me to Chemical Engineering), cosmology, astronomy and astrophotography.

All of this relates to your video in that I’ve done some career wandering, too. I enjoyed your story and hope you personally and with support of your wife and children continue your wandering and stay true to that spirit. And continue to have the good fortune to keep your loves funding your existence.

Congrats and thank you for the explanation that while you must push forward, the path isn't always straight. My father was a graphic designer and photographer in the 1980s, my mother became the defacto IT person at an insurance company when they bought computers but had no one to service them. I started out strattling the line between the technical with learning about websites and graphic design. I eventually decided that design was better off a hobby than a profession (many reasons) and ended up forcing the two together into what later became UI/UX, bringing design principles to software, and how what we take for granted in software can be used to help people. I'm am now also focusing on family. It's without a doubt the best and most important job I've ever had. Props on arriving at a wonderful place in life and continue making science videos. So Im a game developer and Im studying computer science. Ive been making games and learning about computers for 3+ years now and Ive come to a conclusion that computers cannot and will not in the forseeble future take over the world.

The doomsday idea that a sentient computer can take over by learning everything about everyone would require computer the size of a building filled with so much ram and SSD drives just so it wouldnt take years to make a descision that would only have worked however many years ago the data was collected

On top of that, a sentient computer likely wouldnt do anything other than what its programmed to do. Motivation, inspiration and ideas are heavily reliant on chemical reactions in our brains. These reactions go off when something upsetting happens or something happy. They're part of evolution. A computer doesnt have these emotional experiences and doesnt find joy or sadness in what it doesnt. It doesnt care because even if it had the power, intelligence and sentience to take over the world, it wouldnt have the desire. So it would continue to do what it was programmed to.

Hope that makes sense but thats my theory.

I belong to a group which has that one guy, you know the one, the guy who has to put everyone else down, they're stupid, yaddah, yaddah, yaddah. No amount of proof can change his mind due to his own insecurities (I only minored in psych). I graduated with an advanced degree in a STEM field before there were STEM fields. Molecular biology. It was my goal to reprogram pathogenic bacteria and other microbes into producing life saving drugs safely, inexpensively and in a great enough quantity so that no one would have to pay for medicine that they literally needs to survive. Yes, I was monumentally naïve, but, according to this guy, I'm stupid. So, after I quit my field of study after some disturbing talk at a luncheon, I went into drawing comic books for part of a living. I loved it, because it fed my need to create things. It also gave me a great outlet to illustrate complex problems and theories pretty easily. I was feeding my need to study and my need to create, I loved it, and used that in other areas in my life to explain difficult concepts. I love the way you do this with complex problems. In part, I think smart people face a paradox. We learn in school that knowledge and intellectual flexibility are valued, but then we find out... well, no, there's no career path. There are a thousand career paths in which intellectual ability marginally increases your chances of success, but there is no career path in which intellectual ability or the curiosity that must be present to generate it are valued of themselves. You could be an economist who is particularly successful through curiosity and intellectual ability, but you can't be a curious and intellectually able person who is successful on those grounds alone. If you want to make a living and you have to choose between being a dull economist and a bright but unspecialized intellect, you're better off being a dull economist. Any payoff from ability can only be realized within a narrowly focused field, and if you want material success within any narrow field, ability is not your best strategy to get there. We slip through the cracks into contexts in which ability is valued, not the other way around. Ability, of itself, has no value.

It pleases me no end to have discovered your videos a few years back, subscribed, and thereafter not bingeing but watching them as You Tube recommended them to me on any given day that I happened to be browsing, afterwards finding myself always edified and never, ever disappointed. Your life story video was recommended to me today, and at a time I could best use it, as I am currently surmounting a new setback wherein the rebound feels all the more difficult because of my age and the world in general. I have tried and tried again a number of times throughout my life, always standing and thriving anew after each teaching chapter helped me to refine my focus on what is really important to me going forward. In listening to and watching you share the twists and turns of your young and adult life, you remind me that each step I have taken -- most of which I have enjoyed and substantively gained from, a few not so much -- are valuable excursions that, when examined together, constitute the greater adventure that reflects who I am and points me towards who I will ultimately be, for in the end we are the journey. Our circumstances and life stories are not particularly congruent, our backgrounds fairly but not completely dissimilar, but we share interests and also (what I find is key) the heart of a storyteller, and I am so pleased you found the right locale to realize your dream of being the filmmaker and have so generous a disposition in making it real. Your personality and manner of engagement makes Veritasium shine through the cacophony of the Internet -- the YOU that you put into it makes all the difference, at that is the thing that makes all the difference and I appreciate how clear you make that in all your enterprises. You are my definition of a good person, a true citizen of the world, applying and sharing your skills and knowledge to the betterment of all, beginning with yourself and family and outward to your global family of fellow humans, and doing so in a way that seeks to engage and exchange with each and every one of us, for the betterment of us all.  Thank you for being.

I love your story, your intelligence, your sense of service, your delightful family, and your obvious decency and integrity. I studied engineering physics at UBC in the 1980s, around the time you were born, and spent more than half my life in Vancouver or Victoria. I'm in Berlin now.
And like you, I'm doing cool stuff too: Energy system transition modeling and cleantech financial mechanism design.
Here's an idea for Veritasium: Do a prolonged serious on how - in financial engineering and technology buildout terms - the world can rapidly stop putting more CO2 into the atmosphere and move to net negative annual emissions upwards of 30 GtCO2 per annum.
I track this closely in the peer-reviewed press and talk to climate scientists. We will have to achieve net negative emissions on that scale or better ASAP, well before midcentury - we should aim at 2035 with a stretch goal of 2030 - if we're to have any chance of stopping the accelerating ice mass loss from GrIS and WAIS and an irreversible self-reinforcing meltdown dynamic that will culminate with at least ten meters of sea level rise within a century or three. The tipping point is here now - and in fact we may have already passed it; interim solar radiation management may be the only remaining pathway to stabilising the two ice sheets, and at this stage it's not entirely clear that even that would work. 
Do we want to preserve our coastal cities or don't we? It's decision time. It's either already too late or almost too late to stop the self-reinforcing ice sheet melt-down in Greenland and West Antarctica.
What's missing is a sufficient general awareness that with the right financial mechanisms deployed to fund the transition, this is an incredible business and virtuous-circles-rich employment and infrastructure upgrade opportunity, a direct pathway to universal access to cheap renewable energy and back to climate safety too if done at the scale the engineering physics and climate dynamics demand.
We have to understand and deal with this problem as a systems engineering challenge, and just get it done. Our model at LUT (developed by Prof. Christian Breyer et al.) calculates cost-optimal combinations of 120 key infrastructure technologies in a sector-coupled energy systems transition model. 
The way forward in media terms (I'm a recovering business and science journalist) is to interview and convene very smart financial experts with close access to policy leaders, and coax a consensus from them on the optimal design of specific financial instruments. People from ECB, from World Bank, from private finance, from finance academia. We can ask them how we could define the transition in engineering systems pathway terms, figure out what needs to be built in which quantities by when and where, finance the transition, and collectively thrive is so doing. We're setting about putting that question out there.
Maybe that question could be picked up in a Veritasium video series. Maybe that could help change the trajectory of the world a bit. Help bend the curve, Veritasium. As you said so eloquently in your beautiful video: Sometimes trying works. I don't think you used those specific words, but that's what it amounted to. That happens to be my motto. It turns out to be a truth. Sometimes trying does work.

Hey my guy,
I’m currently 23 and I literally lived the same experience than you.
I’ve always wanted to become a successful director but I always closed that possibility choosing to walk the safest path. So abandoning my plans of pursuing a career in filmmaking, I took a diploma of science (which I loved). In 2019 I graduated with a diploma of physics and chemistry in France while spending my third and last abroad at UCLA where I took a lot of film courses, made a film about à character who wasn’t happy and metaphorically representing insecurity and unhappiness of not being at the place you wish you’d be. I won a best directing price. This pushed me towards a new path : filmmaking. I couldn’t take physics anymore, i was at the edge of mentally breaking, it was hard to maintain focus in classes, and having good grades. So I finished my diploma of physics with 10 out of 20 (eq to a 2.0 gpa ??) and then I moved to Montreal after working a year in France to make a living as well as trying to get multiple extra experiences on sets.
Nowadays I’m living in Montreal, Canada working on sets all of my free time while studying film production full time at Concordia.
I’m really glad I took the hardest decision of my life to quit sciences in which I had a bright and well paying future but i knew i was not going to be happy whatsoever.
Now I’m really fulfilled and I enjoy every bits of my new filmmaking career.

I’m not even sure what exactly I want to do, but this video gives me hope. Maybe what I want to do doesn’t exist yet, maybe I’ll invent a new job. Thank you. For all of the Veritasium videos, but also for this video. I have been watching your videos partly because I think science and especially physics is a fascinating subject. The other reason I watch your videos has entirely to do with you. You choose interesting topics within the broad field of physics, you present the concepts in a way that I find engaging and easy to understand (maybe not at first, but always by the end of the video). Also, your personality comes across in a mildly charismatic and comforting way. You seem like a regular person, which is important and not something that I can say about all science educators. It was great to see your early videos with all the clunky awkwardness of anyone beginning a new challenge. I think it is true in almost every case that one of the strongest tools a beginner has is not knowing how bad they are so they can have time to work it all out and not give up before they get going. In acting this can be a challenge since there is no shortage of people willing to point out how bad you are. This can be discouraging especially since everyone in the world will point out that the odds are heavily stacked against you and you rarely hear that everyone was terrible at what they do when they first started out. The thing is, you will always make it at what you want to do if you never give up. Anyway, thanks again. I like your videos and I found your story inspiring. ps - I think Veritasium is a great name for the channel.

Ahh knowledge and the pursuit thereof.... At 62 I have been through fifteen trades always looking to learn. Some of them were short term, not enough to learn to stay interested, others something new every day. Being a computer technician didn't exist when I was left high school in Melbourne in 1975, but it came along and I spent 25 years at it and other things. Life is short. Death is long. The knowledge you acquire begins to dissipate as your brain deteriorates. But the thing you carry with you is the satisfaction and the joy at having packed as much into that fragile container as possible. That and the astonishing joy and trip that is being a parent. Thanks for a continuously interesting series of videos and make the most of your family. Being a parent is the best and most important thing in life.

Derek--
Becoming "entranced" by the subject matter is a major part of having something dramatically important to say-- people sense your interest and excitement, and open their minds to your narrative. Because if there is anything that makes us human, it is that every one of us has a story to tell. We are a communicating, story-telling species.
So, why not communicate your interest in science as your own story? Surely, we have heard of Neil Degrasse Tyson and Carl Sagan, but what many may not know is Tyson deeply admired Sagan, whom he considered his mentor. Sagan demonstrated science is a doorway to knowledge of who we are. As science begets technology at an accelerating pace, we need people who can narrate the drama of this age of discovery.

An Idea for Veritasium might include a much overlooked component of intelligence called Neural Efficiency. Another name is nerve conductive velocity or brain speed. Prof. John Ertl while at Ottawa University worked on the relationship between NE and intelligence and could determine IQ by measuring NE. This got the attention of bioelectric engineer David Graham who having worked with EEG equipment knew that NE was variable. He built a machine called the Graham potentializer that seriously cranked up NE. What he did not know was that IQ was the result of acquired thinking skills while enjoying high NE and that took time. Dr. Frank Begau  created a balance board  that increased NE and had his children using one each day before going to school. Their SAT results were hugely above what otherwise would be expected. He once commented to me that while he and his wife Barbara were quite intelligent their children were standard deviations beyond them. Another interesting fact about NE is that people with high NE are able to make full recoveries from strokes. I know of 3 college professors (High IQ types) who suffered strokes or massive head injuries and trained their way back to teaching college again. Professor Michael Merzenich based his understanding of neural plasticity on the college professor who made a full recovery. They autopsied his brain when he died decades after his stroke and found the stroke area had never recovered and that his brain had rewired itself. I would be happy to tell you more if this interests you. Look for me on facebook in Gold River BC Canada.

A question Zach, and this is coming from out of left field. Full disclosure, I'm not a subscriber (as I'm weighed down by my ethos of 'not missing any of my crowd (aviation ppl) subscribed daily YT uploads - a ton) but I do have Veritasium as a primary top line browser bookmarks). I'm a fan because your channel, Star Talk, Cool Words & Kurgesagt are my prime go-to-channels for nitty gritty subject drilling.

With that said, my question comes 3 minutes into this video, being an avid supporter of 'filming' from a young age, is there a far off chance that you burned up tape experimenting at YVR? I am notorious in aviation (old school aviation - the age of ecological unfriendly aviation) circles for bitching at Canadian Aviation spotters (videographers) for NOT shooting any footage of one of the most illustrious draped airlines in history, CP Air - Canadian Pacific Airways!

Based right there at Vancouver International Airport!

Most dedicated Canadian spotters from the 1980s-1990s are to be found in the east at YYZ & YUL. But there is simply no excuse for YVR spotters to come up as empty as they have. Photos? 1000s...but the photos are great for the age before video. But, no excuses after, especially when film of 1920s, 30s, 40s and 50s of Vancouver and nearly every major city on earth can be seen here on you YT and much of it of pretty impressive quality!

No pressure on you in any way whatsoever...but I've been digging for CP Air footage for over 10 years (if you YT search CP Air, 9/10 will be a snippet of my success)...so yes, I'm at the mercy of individuals dusting off shoe boxes full of film/video (of YVR during those years) and uploading on YT out of boredem OR hoping a BC or Vancouver Televion Station decides to digitize the deteriorating B-roll footage (like the Kino Library) and put out there for us old timers to relieve the golden age of jetliner travel/industry.

So do you by any chance have any test or simple outing shoots of CP Air at YVR? Or any airport from that time period?

Just thought I'd ask and it was a worth it!

Cheers and keep it comin' with the excellent bits of enlightenment!

This is just absolutely inspirational. I'm sure you are told, countless times, how 'lucky' you are. I bring that up because just a short few minutes ago I watched your presentation on the role of luck vs effort or merit. Looking at this piece, what I see is that your 'luck' is comprised of being born to parents who loved each other enough to stay married to each other and  who were determined to see their children succeed by providing for them the best opportunities that could be had. Is it 'luck' ONLY in the sense that it was not due to YOUR efforts, but the effort of others. But, in the grand scheme of things who and what you are today; what you have managed to achieve, artistically and professionally, the percentage attributable to that component that you and others call 'luck' begins to diminish pretty dramatically. That is because it was YOU that charted your course, that had the aspiration and inspiration to pursue other paths, while you also developed your filmmaking career and the requisite skills to be successful in that. You did not meet your beautiful bride, the mother of your children, by happenstance, OTHER THAN, again, what put her in your path and you in hers. While my personal story is utterly different from yours in every single detail, the overarching pattern is not that different. I've had several careers because I failed or got fired or got injured or got divorced and at the occurrence of each of those events, like Newton's laws of motion, my life's trajectory was altered, ever so slightly because I had to make new choices, one of which led me to go back to school where I met my wife. I must now confess to enjoying the free ride on your channel;. I'm not yet a Patreon member. I'm giving that some thought but, in the meantime, Thank You for enriching my life for ten to fifteen minutes at a time.

I like your stuff generally, but this video was very touching. I think your personal career trajectory was just about perfect. Being bright and creative is not good enough to produce the things that you do. You need to be educated enough to understand what you are talking about, and to select things that are worthwhile to communicate. It is refreshing that you are realistic about the fact that luck plays a part in people's success. It is also refreshing that you imply that nobody makes it alone. I had a great career because I was doing what I loved. I hope you are able to continue on with your vision. It's a wonderful thing to be alive at this time in history. We are, I  think, right around the heel of an exponential curve, and shortly, things will shoot straight up. You are a good communicator. You are charismatic on video. Maybe practice makes perfect here. :) Going forward, as evidenced by how frighteningly bungled our COVID response was, we need people who are visible, understand, able to communicate, and engaging enough that people will listen. Anybody who could read a graph knew that we were in imminent danger back in February 2020. In the years ahead, as change accelerates, we are going to need people able to understand and communicate sound advice. Meantime, your focus on your family is where it belongs. They will be your greatest joy, and you will be theirs. Anyway, I greatly enjoyed this video. Cheers!

(sortof)architect here. I really commend and appreciate you telling your story and I found it really inspirational. I personally felt I was more of an artist, always drawing although I did (and still do) have a profound respect for mathematics (logic) although not overly good at it. My parents pushed me towards architecture and I find myself at a crossroads after having come up against some friction with the architectural association and how the profession is practiced in my current/home country Canada. I have worked abroad in Denmark and the Netherlands and found there are more forward thinking ways to use design as a collaborative tool to simultaneously reflect and shape society together rather than as a mere luxury reserved for the few. The truth is everything around us IS designed. I feel there is a real lack of education of the usefulness of design in not only reflecting but shaping our shared environment in North America.

Since before I started school, I knew I wanted to be a scientist of some kind, probably a chemist. When I was five, we came out of the grocery store one day, and when I looked across the street, I spotted a chemistry set in the window of a drug store. I nagged and begged my mother to buy it for me. She had the good sense to realize a five-year-old should not have a chemistry set. One Christmas morning a week before my twelfth birthday I found a chemistry set (Gilbert) and small telescope under the Christmas tree. The following Christmas I got a microscope set (also Gilbert). My journey had begun. Some sixty years later, I still have parts of the chemistry set, Microscope set, and the complete telescope.

One of my favorite places in the world were the science shelves of the local library. I spent many hours looking at and checking out books from those shelves. One of the highlights was the book, "Relativity for the Million" by Martin Gardener that I read when I was thirteen. It was easy to understand and made perfect sense. That book launched my lifelong interest in the works of Albert Einstein and my intense study of both Special and General Relativity. I found a collectors copy of an early edition in excellent condition a few years ago and promptly bought it for my library. If you can find it, it is worth reading. If you cannot find it, you might want to read "Relativity, Simply Explained," also written by Martin Gardner.

As might be expected, my college major was Chemistry, not just any chemistry major, but the American Chemical Society (ACS) Certified Professional Chemist curriculum. It required 43 hours of Chemistry as opposed to the 30 hours required for all other majors. It required a senior research project and paper, which luckily did not have to be defended. I ended up doing two projects, and chose one for my paper. In addition, my minor had to be either Physics or Math, with Physics being the preferred choice. I decided to pursue a double major in both Chemistry and Physics with a math minor. The most difficult part was the four semesters of German (not to mention translating Kafka's insane "Metamorphosis"), with the final course being Scientific German.

Unfortunately, the University had some stupid rule about taking six credits of science in addition to your major and minor, designed primarily for non-science majors. I was trapped in a bureaucratic nightmare having eschewed all science classes outside Chemistry and Physics. I finally had to settle for Chemistry as my major, Math as my minor, and thirty credits of Physics as my “third science.” After five and a half years of university study with 173 credit hours (120 credit hours are normal), this was the disappointing result.

Just for the hell of it, I decided to take the admissions tests for graduate school (GRE), law school (LSAT), and business school (GMAT). Low and behold, I scored high enough to be accepted to all three. I decided not to attend any of them at that time, instead, a friend and I decided to start a small chemical consulting and research company. To be honest, it was all research and no consulting. There is not a lot of call for that kind of work in Southeast Florida. We started doing research on the production of Ethyl Cyanoacrylate, which is the chemical name for the instant glues which used to be marketed as “Permabond”, and “Krazy Glue” just to name a couple. You know, the glue that sticks your fingers together in an instant, but not the object you are actually trying to glue.

One late night we discovered the “Magic Juice”, a mixture of two chemicals that revolutionized the process. As my friend said, it was like something out of an old-time science fiction or horror movie. When we mixed the two liquids, the mixture began to boil and release steam into the air. So, there we stood with this flask of boiling steaming liquid, what choice did we have but to add it to the large flask containing the raw materials for the reaction. That along with two other changes in the process allowed us to run the initial reaction at a greatly reduced temperature, with about a fifty percent increase in the percentage yield.

Ethyl cyanoacrylate is a monomer (single molecule) that uses water to polymerize (multiple molecules bonded together into a long chain), so it has to be distilled in a vacuum to keep out all moisture. We could distill with higher pressures and we had completely eliminated the problem of polymerization in the vacuum pump which used to gum it up making it necessary to constantly take it apart to clean it. We also had a better stabilizer for the finished product, which allowed my friend to store a bottle of the finished glue for almost 20 years without any degradation. Alas, no one wanted to buy our process. We did not patent it, and we chickened out at the thought of manufacturing the clue ourselves. I have not checked on the manufacturing process employed nowadays, so I have no idea if they are still using the antiquated, inefficient process we started with. I also occasionally wonder if anyone else discovered our "Magic Juice," or any of the other improvements we discovered 45 years ago.

I ended taking a job as an industrial R&D Chemist with a medium sized paint and coatings company. Of all the work I did, my most ambitious project was developing a paint for the airplanes of a commercial airliner (United). Airplanes are notoriously difficult to paint, because they are made out of aircraft grade aluminum, and all aluminum alloys are almost impossible to paint. The challenge was to make a paint that resists the actions of the harsh cleaning chemicals, aircraft hydraulic fluid, and aircraft fuel. It has to be tough enough to resist the wind abrasion while being shiny and flexible enough to resist the cold, and rippling of the surface encountered in high altitude flying.

Painting airplanes is a four-step process. The surface has to be cleaned, then a coating called a wash-coat primer is applied, followed by an epoxy-urethane primer, and finally a catalyzed urethane topcoat. My job was to develop the latter three-part paint system. After a year and a half, I was ready for a real-world test. The paint had passed every laboratory test, so I made a couple of gallons of each of the three-part system and sent it out to be painted on a section of an airplane. Horrors, it flaked and peeled off after a few hours of flight. I eventually solved the problems, but our company’s ridiculous pricing policy made it too expensive, so almost two years of hard work was for naught. It was then that I decided to enroll in the MBA program at out local university. After two years, I finished the degree and my company offered me a management position with all kinds of pie in the sky offers. When it came to actually negotiating my salary and benefits, the cheap owner began hemming and hawing and paring down the offer until it was so poor that I would have been a fool to stay. I ended up moving into a management position with a local manufacturing company. It didn’t take long to realize that this was a big mistake and that I hated that kind of work.

I decided to try teaching for a year or two while I decided what I really wanted to do for the rest of my life. To my surprise, it turned out to be teaching. I had a 33-year career teaching, and while some of it has been tumultuous and frustrating, it was my passion. Really knowledgeable Physics teachers are very hard to find, so they are in high demand, so I could pretty much pick and choose where I taught. I decided to pursue a graduate degree in Physics, which took quite a while as I tried to find classes I could attend while I worked full time. I eventually finished my M.S. With only an M.S. a professorship at a university is pretty much out of the question. In addition, while the teaching load was much lighter, the salary and benefits were also MUCH LOWER. At best, I could be a full-time instructor, but never a tenured professor, so High School is where I went. The aggravating part is that I am a much better teacher than most of the professors I had, who stood at the board delivering dry long-winded lectures as they wrote endless equations on the board with virtually no explanations while students struggled to copy the equations so they could go off on their own to decipher the scribblings. A PhD does not necessarily produce a great teacher, something Universities should consider.

People who have known me for a long time will say they are not surprised I ended up teaching, because I was always teaching my entire life. Anytime I discovered something new and interesting, I had to pass it along to everyone I could get to listen, often boring them to death because they had no interest in what I was talking about. I count my wife as a success story because she now knows more about physics than most people, including many marginal Physics teachers I have met along the way. She even follows several science related sites on Facebook.

This February (2021), I will be retired six years, and I still miss teaching. I watch YouTube videos and when I see something interesting or unusual, I begin to think about how to use it in my classroom. Then I remember, I have no classroom anymore, so I inflict my lessons on unsuspecting YouTube watchers in the comments section. I also satisfy my need to teach by frequenting homework help sites and the Physics and Chemistry pages on Quora. The difference is that they all have the option to ignore my writings while my students were captives. LOL.

Today I am in the process of building an old-fashioned lab bench in my garage based on a picture I cut out of a magazine many decades ago. I ended up pursuing my dream without realizing it was my dream when I started out those many years ago looking at that chemistry set in the drugstore window.

Wayne Y. Adams

Brought me to tears. Not just because it was so heartfelt and personal, but because I relate to your story so much. First I want to thank you for sharing and being so candid. Success stories are a beautiful thing -- art in and of themselves -- but the ambition, drive, motivations behind the path to success can sometimes be really really nasty.

When I was in engineering school at GA Tech my advisor looked at the German and French classes on my schedule and said, "You're not thinking like an engineer." I was so offended I started an argument and he promptly kicked me out of his office, telling me go find another advisor. I graduated, albeit barely, thinking I was on my way to fulfilling my dream to one day be an astronaut and go to mars. Ah, but the Challenger had blown up that year and there were no jobs in Aerospace.

So after getting rejected by literally every aero firm in the U.S., when I finally managed to land a job, I immediately discovered computer programming, which I fell in love with, so I (painfully) made that transition. And I eventually secured a team lead position at the Red Cross. But I was also inseparable from my creative side. For me it was poetry and songwriting, so I pursued that alongside my "real" job, and eventually managed to join a band, play out, and even write/record my own album. Oh but I was also very into cognitive science, AI, and neurology; so I was pursuing my masters as well...

Then 9/11 happened. And none of those goals seemed to matter; so after podcasting for a while I started writing a novel about...well, a guy who drops his plans for college after 9/11 and joins the military to go off and save the world. And the book was finally published in 2016, but it's not like I was an author, really. And, just like you mentioned about filmmaking, that business is no meritocracy. So the novel could become the next Confederacy Of Dunces, but great reviews are no guarantee, and to rely on other people's interests -- or their awareness, or even their assessment of what good art even is -- is an extremely dangerous thing. So only time will tell. But it took a long time for me to recognize becoming a published author as my absolute greatest accomplishment, odd as that may sound.

It's now 25 years after I started my career, I am working as an engineer in Germany (take that, Ducoff! haha) and yet still unsatisfied and ambitious and dreaming and, well, trying to decide what I want to be when I grow up. So yes, it is fine to lie to yourself and say you not only CAN do anything but will one day do EVERYTHING. Just make damned sure you never wake up one day to its doppelganger, truth, staring you in the face, grinning. Because that is scary AF, believe me. What really matters in the end, as David Brooks has pointed out, is how much you have helped those around you, not some arbitrary societal notion of success you have internalized or fed off of because it was so intoxicating.

That said... I find it befuddling when smart, talented people gain an incredible education and then turn on a dime and pursue something else. This is a subject worthy of considerable investigation and study, if you ask me. The amount of time, money and energy invested in a pursuit by the individual as well as society absolutely wasted in an instant. Well, not completely wasted, but not getting anyone's money's worth. Stories like this abound and it's unfortunate. It's inefficient and it acts to derail the dreams of others. If your heart wasn't in studying engineering and physics, then it's a shame. A shame that your spot in engineering school was taken and the kid who's entire life dream to study engineering was thwarted. Think of all the coveted professional higher education pursuits that are simply wasted by fickle, but very smart people, who once they finish, abandon everything they've learned for an alternate career path or passion.

Now it would be nice if our current economy allowed for this fickle change in interest. But school admissions are limited, competition is beyond extreme, and only very few get to pursue these lofty goals. Perhaps it shouldn't be the "smartest," but those with the most desire and enthusiasm.

Only 52 seconds into this video, but I know one thing about this dude's life story because I went to a little high-school called 'Lavalla Catholic College' which Derek probably knew as 'Catholic Regional College', or, 'CRC'.

Just one thing I happen to know about him. Everyone wants to be a cosmopolitan these days, but I'm all about community pride. I'll probably end up being a millionaire, maybe even a billionaire, one day, and when that day arrives you'll still find me in my same shitty house in Traralgon asking my mate Royce, who studied economics and finance, whether he's had any tenbaggers recently. Point being, while most live like they were inspired by Eminem when he said "We all long to blow up and leave the past behind us. Along with the small fries and average half-pinters." I wax poetic about how there 'must be something in the water' around these parts because we've produced people like Veritasium's Derek, Zach from Aunty Donna, Mark (augmented reality artist) from marcomatic.com, Josiah (Jezza) from Drawing With Jezza, my finance guy Royce, and myself. There are loads of creative geniuses around here, and it's kind of strange. Like, if Stratford-upon-Avon not only produced Shakespeare, but Spinoza and Da Vinci as well.

I know national pride is pretty taboo for European descendants since, you know... That whole 'Pan-Germanism' thing... But I'd hope Veritasium can appreciate, and accept thanks for, the small amount of community pride I feel from people like Derek. Even though he clearly is the kind of cosmopolitan I am not.

Really cool channel, Derek - you've created something that isn't anchored or attached to any one subject or interest...you can take it anywhere you want.

Here's an idea - there are many of us out here who have tried, failed, succeeded, failed, succeeded...you get the point. Lots of career paths. Lots of experiences. Lots of situations, circumstances, and so on. But what you could do - since you're looking for ideas - is to explore the Law of Cause and Effect. I too, am tired of watching billionaires tell me "This is how I did it!" I know several billionaires and more than my share of multi-millionaires and, almost to a person, they ascribed luck as the main driver. Where they were, who they happened to meet, that sort of thing.

One would think that planning and strategizing properly would be the main driver of success. And while they are important and probably required, the honest assessment of almost everyone I've talked to who's achieved success - and even many who haven't or just out-and-out failed - was the aforementioned luck scenario.

I offer this up because I fall into both camps - success and failure - and have clawed my way to where I am not by having any unique skill or quality other than determination and perseverance. But even that sounds hackneyed and trite, doesn't it? So that's why a YouTube channel such as yours would do it a much better service than just writing about it.

My best friend started with an intention he wasn't even aware of at the time.  As long as I've known him (approaching four decades) he's enjoyed listening to someone, anyone really, tell their story.  We'd be walking down the street and he'd stop to chat with a telephone lineman, or a young woman hanging a poster, or a street vendor.  Within a minute or two an engrossing conversation would evolve.  He went on to found a company that makes video editing systems, so that tens of thousands of people could tell their story in film.  That company became successful, which was of course wonderful, but not absolutely necessary.  His intention was (and is) so simple it is simply *unstoppable*.  Even if the company had failed he would have found a way to realize his fundamental intention, because he simply finds joy in helping people tell their story.  I imagine there is an intention buried in Derek's love of science and the arts that is unstoppable, an intention that would somehow have been realized even if his YouTube venture failed.  I can't say exactly what it is; perhaps even he cannot, but it's clearly there.  So it may not be true that "you can achieve anything your heart desires", but if you allow the ideas and activities that truly energize you to have their way, if you allow an intention of the unstoppable variety to grow, you will not fail.

I don't think people are inherently lazy or hard working. I think there are people who have found what they really want in life, and those who haven't figured it out. If someone is excited and inspired to do something, they will work hard for it no matter who they are. If something makes them unhappy and doesn't seem worthwhile, they won't work hard for it, or at least not for long.

As for finding what you want in life, I think a lot of that is random. How you were raised, who you were friends with, what you did with your friends, what abilities or disabilities you were born with. Some things we can control, but there is a lot we can't.

I think at the end of the day you just have to learn to be okay with who you are and realize life takes longer to figure out for some people than others. Maybe you'll have some big epiphany that changes your life, or maybe you'll just do a little better this year than you did last year. What you love today you might hate tomorrow, and what you hate today you might love tomorrow.

Just my 2 cents, based on what I know. Good luck.

The life story that I never knew I wanted and needed to know... just cool. And wow. My literal dream, as simpleton and pitiful as it sounds, is to be a PhD. Whether in computer science, computer engineering, software engineering, aerospace engineering, electrical engineering, or some degree focused around genetics or genetic engineering. Sad thing, and this really isn’t a pity party on my part, is that I just don’t have the means to. Not at this point. I wish I had focused more in my life’s educational “Goldilocks zone”.
But I didn’t, so I do the best I can and I work a regular job and I satisfy my deep need to learn and research and feel like I’m progressing or doing something in some way by reading a lot, playing a ton of simulation type games, watching YouTube videos about calculus and space and chemistry, and generally just learning more and more stuff that really serves no necessity in my life because I made mistakes when I was younger that I didn’t realize would be the kind of mistakes that you can never reverse. Lol.
One thing I do want to say to kids and generate just younger people out there, is this. Don’t for a second take for granted your education, no matter how formal or outdated you think the educational system is. Because bottom line is, if you don’t have one, you’ll never be an engineer or rocket scientist or molecular engineer by self-teaching. And you’ll never get the job you want or push the boundaries of your most loved field of science by just learning on the internet and YouTube. You just have to have that piece of paper, and you have to go through the formal motions of getting a degree from an accredited college.
Don’t think for a second, or let someone tell you that the only way you can mess up your life is to like, be a felon or drug addict or commit murder and be thrown in jail for the rest of your life. Because I never did any of those things, and I’ve affectively crippled my future by thinking “idk exactly what I want to do and I can’t have the things I want to have so I’m just going to quit school and work full time for now so I can be more independent”. Believe me. It’s not a good feeling to look back and think, “I had the perfect opportunity to study, get through college, and come out in the end with a degree I could have used to go anywhere. But because I didn’t do it then, I’ve lost that chance forever.”
I’d love to see new generations keep on doing and discovering and creating and inventing new and better things. No matter what.
Anyway, I know I rant. I have a bad habit of doing that, and I just really wanted to express how awesome I though this video was and how it affected me.

survivor bias. nice term. i did at least try to follow my dream. when all my friends were registering at universities, setting themselves up to study things like medicine and engineering, i instead looked for work so that i could save up to become a pilot. this, despite discovering after high school graduation that i had a slight degree of colour blindness - enough to be detected during my aviation medical. i went on to do other tests and worked very hard to prove that my colour deficiency was not severe enough to keep me from flying safely. in the end, the regulatory body agreed to allow me to fly but privately - not as a commercial pilot. and i never could make the money to fly. not a day goes by that i desperately wish i could fly for a living. at least i gave it a good shot. but yes, easy for those whom have been fortunate enough to realise their dreams to tell others that anything is possible.

I'm a self taught software engineer. I came from a rough upbringing that ended in both of my parents passing right after high school, so it wasn't really possible for me to follow the traditional path. It took many long hard years (12 professionally, 25 total to be exact) to get from where I began to where I am now, and some of those years include a very near run in with homelessness when I was dependent upon food banks to survive. I think survivor bias is biased towards paying attention to the many people who have put in half-hearted attempts, which aren't even close to the amount of effort, try, and retry that's necessary to achieve your dreams. I do think that you have 100% chance of succeeding at anything you try given you don't stop trying and enough time. There's no such thing as failing what you have yet to stop trying.

As a recent grad I’ve been really worried about whether I should pursue my dream career as a researcher/lecturer or just prioritise job security and get “safer” qualifications instead. The job market in my area really isn’t big for research, and given the current job insecurity and hyper-specialisation of PhD grads I was worried that I was being deluded by survivorship bias and was close to giving up on what was my goal for the last three years. My Honours supervisor recommended your channel to show me that science communication is still possible outside the academic space, and this is the first video of yours that I watched. Thank you for showing me that it’s ok if you don’t have everything figured out straight away, and that you can make “the wrong decisions” along the way and even be disappointed during your PhD and still have things work out. This really helped
Beautiful. Inspiring. Motivating. Am very glad I stumbled upon this.

Well, I can't think of a more timely video.  But not the time you released it 2 years ago, but now, the time I just watched it.  Just turned 61 and this pandemic has reset my life in some surprising and hopefully positive ways.  While on my nightly walks and runs made possible (and therapeutically necessary) by the pandemic, I've been listening to a string of books on Audible that have expanded my mind while strengthening my body: "Midnight in Chernobyl" , "Atomic Habits", "The Emperor of All Maladies",  "Lifespan" (fittingly finished the day after my 61st birthday), and currently "How to Change Your Mind" (exploration of psychedelics).  Now that David Sinclair has convinced me that aging is a disease, living healthily to 100 seems quite doable, and so I'm considering a whole new career in something I'm actually passionate about.  Thanks for your encouragement to reach for my passion.  Though I may fail in a particular pursuit, it's the reaching that's important, as you so eloquently phrased it.  Thanks!

I really love watching your videos. Especially your playlist explaining misconceptions. I steal your ideas and teach them to my 6 year old daughter in the same way that you do. We talk  about where trees might get their wood from, which leads to the idea that the elements are the building blocks of different things. I try to get her to really understand what inertia is, and how it is different but related to mass and weight, using practical experiments around the home. I love that you identify that some scientific concepts are intuitive (we just need to learn the scientific names for them), while other scientific concepts can be completely counter intuitive (like the idea that matter and energy can be transformed into each other in nuclear processes). What I would love you to do - and i think you are in a unique position to do it - is list all the laws of physics in order of "most intuitive" to "least intuitive". I think this would make a great playlist, starting with the most an progressing to the least intuitive laws of physics. Anyway - keep up the great work !!

The chicken-vs-egg career issue is so fascinating to me. Passion for one subject (film) is not necessarily going to end with a sustainable career, as the arts are not an economic priority in our culture. Combining the art passion with the science cred is what gives you a sustainable career, so the "backup" educational choices were critical to eventual success and not really a backup at all. No great point I'm making here, except that a "pure" arts career, without the science education included, is still not widely viable, at least in the US.

I have benefited tremendously from Veritasium over the years. Being a physicist myself (and one who spends quite a bit of time on YouTube) my feed is naturally filled with science goodies. There's you and Numberphile and Scishow and VSauce and 3Blue1Brown and so many wonderful sources of knowledge and - perhaps even more importantly - inspiration. We need inspiration to keep going. It is the fuel that keeps the flame lit and bright, and I honestly think you have been excelling at being a provider of inspiration. Can you imagine the number of people out there that you have reached and whose lives have been improved one way or another by just letting your brain chat with theirs? You do have a lot to be proud of!

I myself have tons to thank. Today you have helped to cool down my nerves a bit in the stress that comes from this whole pandemic mess. But there was another day where I was helped by learning a neat way to explain one concept or another from your videos. And there was even another day when I was helped with some key understanding about the topic of the trial lecture I had to give to defend my own PhD (the trial lecture topic in Norway where I took my degree is chosen 2 weeks prior to the defense, and mine was on the transport of water in plants. I can't tell you how much I benefited from your video on that!) So yeah, those are a couple of concrete examples, and I am sure I am only one in a multitude of science lovers out there who have been benefiting tremendously from the privilege and joy of having folks like you as our sources of information and entertainment.

Keep doing what your heart and mind tell you you should do. You're making this world a tiny bit better by doing just that. Super cute kids also, they are super lucky to have you and your girl around!

Hi  Just saw your video on who you are.  Great presentation.   You asked for suggestions about what to do with your time.  I believe there are two answers.  One answer is in helping others and thereby helping yourself.  Canadian Doctor Hans Selye who was the world's leading authority on stress, said that the key to happiness was "altruistic egoism" which means you help others with the knowledge that you yourself will benefit.   Personally I believe that the best way to help mankind is through genetic research which will lead to discoveries that will end disease.   The second answer is in your relationship with your children.  At the end of your life you will look back on your life and you will note that nothing is more valuable than what you did with your children as their father.   The key to that is how much love did you give them.   How much joy did you give them?  How much  advice did you give them about coping with the world so they could carry on with their own life?   When my 92 year old grandmother was dying I was alone with her and all she said was "I love you, I love you, I love you".  That's what life comes down to.  Don Queen's grad 1976

Fantastic video, and inspiring story. Congratulations. No need to thank us in the audience though - your videos are popular and you have 6.62m subscribers because your content is truly excellent. Your success is well deserved.

I've often thought that the right advice to someone considering taking a 'statistically unlikely to succeed, follow your passion' path is 'don't do it', because the people that are going to succeed are going to ignore the advice and do it anyway, and for everyone else, it's good advice! :-)

But in all seriousness, I think what your life story shows is that if you have a passion for something, and are dedicated in your work, you can't help but get very good at it over time. And if you get good at something, you possess something that the world will value (the world needs people that are good at doing things), and so you will in all likelihood eventually find a way to put those skills and knowledge to work in a way that works for you and the world, even if the exact path to how is not yet immediately clear to you.

You can't beat passion and obsession. Passionate people don't just get good/ok at things - they get great at them. And you can add more value to the world (and be a lot happier) doing something you're great at than something your just ok at.

Thanks for sharing your story, & for all your great work.

Hey Derek. I must say I always loved to watch your videos, but the ones that always touched me the most were those which offered additional inside on the place we all live in: Planet Earth. If it was about the physics inside of trees or gravitational effects observable here on the ground, those were the most amazing. To me. Since I know what it feels like to have kids, raise them, watch them grow and finally find to start their own life's, I also know what makes me afraid the most of. Have I brought my kids to live in a dying world? One that I too am guilty to have brought to its knees? And every day I ask myself: what can I do to change that? As an educator working with kids on a daily basis, I guess I have some influence on some kids I learn to know, but will they still heed my advice when they grow up? Will they remember my words in a couple of years? Actually, I doubt that.
But you, you use a modern and adequate medium to reach people all across the world with content that really matters, including kids. So how about talking more than you already did about all the things we can do to make this world a better place again? For the kids we will leave behind some day. People like you, with their appearance on one of the most beloved entertainment platforms of today's youths, have a much bigger influence on them then people like me have, despite working with them daily. And it's not that I am unpopular amongst the kids at my school, but in a couple of years they will have forgotten me. Your videos, they will stick.
Almost daily I meet people, young and old, who are widely unaware about many aspects that make this planet the place it is. Maybe bringing more light into the effects of things, even little ones, we can do to change the current course of climate change might be a thing?
That way I can at least always point to your videos when kids are asking me about the world of their future...
Anyway, whatever you go on to, I will always enjoy watching your videos, for me they are amongst the best things you tube has to offer.

Derek touched on a point which deserves amplification. I suspect that many Veritasium viewers are like I was 50 years ago — smart, ambitious and determined to make a mark. I went to Medical School and at the age of 30 opened my practice. Marriage followed at 35, and a baby at 41. It was at this pivotal point that I made the smartest decision of my life. I promised myself that I would order my priorities in a rigid, nonnegotiable way:
#1. My son. I gave him a minimum of 1 hour of time devoted exclusively to him every day. 90 minutes - 2 hours was more typical, much more on weekends. I read to him before bed for 30-45 minutes every night, with exceptions that were truly rare. We read Dinotopia, 3 times. Lord of the Rings twice. Winnie the Pooh. C.S. Lewis. And Lots of Mark Twain, Steinbeck. Harry Potter, of course. Introductions to complexity theory. Wind in the Willows. Dickins. Tolstoy. We even did bits of the Tao Te Ching sporadically, until he caught on to it, and read it on his own. At age 12. We did kitchen counter science, from simple stuff up to deriving a couple of Newtons laws of motion from kitchen experiments. Models, tandem bike riding, skiing, martial arts (we didn't send him. We did it with him, so he stuck to it). And stupid, stupid games. We made up dozens. And we talked about anything, and everything.
#2. My work was almost co-#1. I never let the quality drop. I found that I would reschedule work for my son, but never the other way around.
#3. My wife. Poor girl, but she understood.
#4. Everybody else.
My wife and I are each prone to moodiness. Our son is the most stable, well-adjusted 29 year old I've ever met, and the most consistently happy. He works and excels at what he loves, and continues to pursue the activities we did when he was a kid — although he's added rock climbing and base jumping.
My point is, Derek, and anyone else with small children — if you want your kids to turn out happy, compassionate, intelligent and curious, and with a good social conscience, you MUST impart those qualities to them, and you MUST spend massive amounts of time with them playing and teaching. you can't farm it out. They'll pick up a matrix for ethical growth somewhere; if it isn't from you, it will be from TV.

I believe I was born a graphic designer. It's all I thought about and did when I was a kid. I currently hold a B.A. degree in Graphic Design and will graduate with a B.S. Mechanical Engineering degree in December.

The interesting part is the two disciplines have always been one and the same to me. . . I know. But it's something that's always been difficult for me to explain. It still is.

My simplest explanation is that I see Graphic Designers and Mechanical Engineers as creatives who just use different tools ("medium" in design-speak). The two disciplines are intentional in their goals. Each one is trying to make life better, easier and more enjoyable.
Graphic Design is liberating in terms of what I can imagine (great for creativity) and Mech. Eng. brings the practicality. In a way, the graphic designer in me dreams and the engineer makes those dreams come true.

More often than not formal education prescribes a person's scope of practice which is a good thing because it makes it easier for different disciplines to coexist and fit into society, but creativity is the bedrock of modern life. Most non-conformers stick out like misfits; at least initially. And I believe we are living off the work of those misfits. Galileo, Kepler and Tesla all had to break with convention at some point otherwise their discoveries may have remained secrets.

Allowing our unique experiences to permeate our creative processes is neccessary for unveiling new secrets; regardless of one's discipline.

More seriously, I was so moved, I cried. Relating so much, and just hope my shift moment (or 'phase shift' is coming). I am so tied down in a family crises that has not yet resolved after 2 decades. Locked in. Synchronistic - I did an audio today specifically raising the selection bias concept applying it to the uncertainty of my current situation and challenges. Glad I am not the only person that identifies this. Oh boy, still really emotional. I have seen so much, and to my surprise most of it is coming true as the last 4 decades unfold. Always alone in what I see so I reject the likelihood of its validity. The convergence of validities now to the point at times I go from deep doubt to fear of having fundamentally failed in a terrible way because I did not have the courage and trust in what I see. I felt dissuaded through being the only one standing where I was in what I saw at the time on so many things. Silence and disinterest from peers can be so much more powerful in silencing the mind than open objection. I guess the more you see, the more you see so many possibilities and cognitive uncertainty goes up. Only in time does the robust insight reveal itself originally so tentatively held, as valid. To think being geek is now trendy. I have already done the modern AI as an algorithmic concept before anyone in modern times as far as I can tell. I had a job in a government science lab at the time, and no one thought it was of any value. Huh, the irony and I just laugh at the situation. Really I do. I find it so funny, the irony. What else can I say. Do you want the conceptual leap for a UFT with this? Maybe, possibly not. No idea. Cheers.

You asked for our input on what's next, so here you go: 

In any market, the winners are those who manage to cut through the noise and offer their customers something unique. There are myriad science videos out there, but what makes yours so unique is your honesty. You have made it clear time and time again that truth is paramount. If you discover new evidence that requires you to shift your paradigm, you're not afraid to do so. You seem to embody the very heart of good science. You are not trying to be correct all the time, but just finding the truth.

In a way this gives you a ton of freedom! Whatever content you decide to go with, I know you will manage to make it personal, unique, and inspiring. Your authenticity will propel your content. Having said that, I know the market has trends. You are obviously much more in tune with those trends than I am since you are on the front lines. So the question you should answer is will you try and follow the trends or will you lead with something completely unique?

I think you would do very well making videos about your passions. If family is where you are at right now, make some content about family dynamics, sociology, psychology, even physics! There is some amazing physics at work when a shoe comes untied. What about improving play equipment? How often have we gone for cheap instead of safe and how often have we ignored good physics when building our toys? I know that's a little out there, but you get my point.

Best of luck in all your endeavors! God bless.

I'm honestly so thankful for this video. When I was younger, I was a top student. While I was in high school, I was also enrolled in college. My high school was one of a kind at the time (it still might be, but I'm not sure). I took legitimate college classes at a university and graduated high school with 3/4 of my BS in Electrical Engineering. I got married right after I graduated high school (yes, I'm still married and I am the happiest I could ever be), and my plan was to finish my degree in the state I moved to. But, life had different plans. At the time, it was frustrating. The school I attempted to go to didn't allow online lab classes, and the physical school was over 4 hours away. There was no way it could work, and at the time, full online classes were just becoming a thing. It was impossible to finish my degree in that state, but we were stuck there due to the military. But, looking back, it was a blessing in disguise. While we lived there, I came to the realization that I did not want to be an engineer. I loved learning and I still do, but as I really thought about it, spending my life as an engineer would be a dagger in my stomach. Instead, I was forced to spend some one on one time with myself and figure out what I REALLY wanted to do with my life: art and writing. The state we lived in was Hell. I hated it. The only way I really stayed sane there (besides my wonderful husband's support) was through art and writing. My son was born, and my husband gave me the chance to stay at home with him and pursue my passions. My best friend and I began a writing project that we are now seeking agents for, and I realized my true calling in life. I can't even imagine what my life would be like if I had finished my degree. I know I would feel trapped. So many people tell me that not pursuing engineering was a mistake, that I should be more accepting of my intelligence, and that I would be getting great money as an engineer. I tell them that there is more to life than a career, more to life than personal gifts, and more to life than money. I am incredibly thankful for the opportunity and support my husband has given me. I'm thankful for that frustrating point in my "career" as an engineer. It forced me to wait and realize I wanted something completely different out of my life. Writing has also given me a realization that I adore learning about planets and their properties, and I have a deep interest in quantum mechanics. At some point in the future, I may pursue a degree in astronomy! My writing (realistic Scifi and Fantasy) has pushed me to learn more about random topics, and your channel has helped me so much with understanding some of those concepts that I put into our books. I'm excited to see that you have always had a passion for the arts too and you questioned your interest in engineering like I did. You're brilliant, and you're helping people who have gone through that "I'm not sure about this" moment like you did. I can only hope that my life path leads me to helping people like you do. Please keep it up, and enjoy your time with your family!!
