"..the students were great, the pay was great..." but you weren't doing what you wanted to do. How 'great' is that? As an engineer and physicist it should be obvious how to do something. Apply the scientific method. Define the parameters of what it is, read the available literature, repeat some of the experiments. Understand the subject, become conversant in it (this is plugging you into the subject) and then extend the subject. For filmmaking this is not hard to figure out. You watch movies, you read scripts, you figure out what you like about certain movies, what you don't like about others-- more importantly you closely examine movies that have been esteemed for a long time (Yes that movie that is a year old seems to be pure genius, but no one will be sure about that for at least 10-20 years). Some of those old masterpieces are just okay, but many of them are brilliant. The path then isn't going to film school, it's writing scripts, acting, learning how stories work, understanding photography/cinematography.

Call up or write people doing the job you want to do, ask questions, ask for work, and now because it is so cheap, just start making movies.

This of course is for someone else; as it's too late for you. You're making 'great videos on your YouTube channel, making great pay, meeting great people...and you're likely to end up working for a text book company or a TV station (pray you don't). What I've learned in my so far failure to become a novelist is that it is more satisfying to learn how the people who do it well have done it more so than to plug into the academic angle on the subject. So figuring out by yourself, how did Charlotte Bronte did it, is (I think) much better than getting a PhD in English Lit and becoming a professor, even though it pays great, you meet a lot of great people, etc.... Denis Diderot was completely successful.

On survivor bias and 'logical choice' (10:01):
It can be quite logical to try to achieve statistically very unlikely things, the upside potential just has to be good enough.

You worked and put valuable pieces together (PhD, film/acting/style), and in a way that few did —so it's not clear what your 'chance' of getting what you wanted was. I'm not sure that 'chance' is even the right term; you hardly played a random-numbers game, and had you 'lost' (as you did at times) you would've redefined what you wanted and continued to try to get that.

Seconds in a day =86,400 
Weight of a mol ( 6.02x10 to the 23rd  molecules) of vitamin C =176 grams

(0.0000568) x ( 6.02 times 10 to the 23rd)

3.42x10 to the 19thelectrons available if you eat 100 mg of vitamin C

It's common to wander around and stumble into your groove. When I was younger I would never have imagined myself operating a service business that caters almost exclusively to other businesses, government's, NGO's and charities providing advanced IT services. And not only that, but I'm one of the go to people in my local market.

I didn't have a clue in high school. The Navy thought I'd make a good electronics technician. Boy, were they right! I parlayed that into a job in the telecommunications industry. Then I started my own business in 1999 and it's been growing ever since. My cell has over 600 contacts in it now! And I've never paid one dime for advertising!

Some of my larger customers have been Carl Zeiss Vision & Optics Corporation, Facebook, the U.S. Army Tactical Command (TACOM) in Warren Michigan, and Phillips Automotive Lighting.

I’m an English student at University, who, after serving 5 years in the Forces, decided to give undergraduate study a try.

Well, I thew my grist to the mill, and by the recommendation of others I ended up taking the “safe” option. For me, that was English. I always excelled at it, and it felt like it was something I could accomplish. I’ve had my life planned out for me by my family: undergraduate study in English Literature through to Phd followed by a career as a lecturer, professional academic, or even breaching the world of journalism.

But the problem is, it’s not me. It is not where my heart lies. The very fact that I’m on your channel testifies to the fact that I have at least a passing interest in the Sciences. But it runs deeper than that. I’m attempting to self-teach basic calculus, I have changed my single-track for a dual-honours split with Philosophy (and subsequently taken a module in Elementary Logic, which I love), and I would rather read around scientific literature that I barely understand than engage with degree-relevant material. It’s not because I’m a procrastinator though, although I am. It is because I can read through a section of prose and, even after having accurately interpreted it, I don’t get the same buzz that I receive when I’ve understood some scientific principle or law. But your videos are what life is all about to my mind—working out what our world means, how best to understand it, and communicating that insight to the largest number of people.

See, I’ve come to understand that I’m a scientist at heart, and always have been. I want to combine my penchant for problem-solving and abstract domains with my growing affinity with numbers, and to do so in a domain that offers tangible, practical applications for such practices. I now know what I want: a degree in physics with modules in astrophysics, then to apply to NASA. I want to be on the cutting edge of science, and to be involved in the ultimate human endeavour: cosmic exploration. While astronaut applications are extremely competitive (my specific interest), if I don’t try I will never forgive myself.

I always wanted to conquer Everest, ever since my grandparents told me their stories about Sir Ranulph Fiennes, whom they both knew. But videos like these helped me to understand who I am, and who I want to be. My Everest will be the eternal vacuum which surrounds our planet. My conquest will be either achieving, or helping others to achieve feats of space exploration.

So, to wrap this up in a point: without videos likes these I wouldn’t feel inspired to dare chasing that dream. As it is, I have ordered books on basic physics and maths, and I will set about turning that dream into reality.

Is it because we all want to be billionaires? I definitely don't think that this is what everyone wants, although most people would like it. Why do people end up doing things that they don't like? Enjoyment and living life in a positive way should be the goal, not survival, at least in the long run. We can all agree that working a 9-5 in a small office every day isnt attractive and can actually be harmful to one's health. So why do people do this? To live life? Hell no, they do it for survival, for security, and im not saying this is wrong but the conventional ways of obtaining these needs are generally hostile towards us, but we still choose them. Hi Derek! I might have a suggestion (see below heading for TLDR).
This video was truly inspiring to me and really struck a chord. It would seem you and I have a similar past. I too struggled with feeling stifled in the past due to choosing a safe path over my desired path. I have spent the past 10 years regretting the decision that I made.


Background:
I found out in high school that I really enjoyed programming and computer science. However, I did not believe that I was capable of achieving my goal (I grew up in a poor household, being told my entire life that I would amount to very little by those I considered friends). So, I chose the safe and "high paying" route of architectural technology. I had no passion for architecture, no creativity in the field and experience extreme depression due to a lack of purpose. For 7 years following my graduation, I sought a way of entering into the computer science field without having to go back to school (I have few mental disabilities and school is unnecessarily difficult for me due to all of its redundant rules and archaic grading structure). In 2017, I finally bit the bullet and returned to university to obtain a degree in computer science. It has been a difficult path, but so very rewarding. While in the program, my interests have grown and honed in on AI and applying it to space application (rover course plotting, image processing, the search for ET life, etc.). Now, I am in the process of preparing for my master's degree (via project courses in my 4th year) where I will be researching AI applications on Mars (a massive jump from my humble beginnings).


Suggestion:
You asked for suggestions for the future of this channel. I think there are many people just like you and me who feel they are meant for something greater/different than their current circumstance. Maybe they want to invent something revolutionary, rise above their economic standing, or express who they are through their chosen medium. Maybe they have something to offer to science or a certain industry, but cannot figure out how to make the correct connections. Most of them could really use an opportunity to do so. But first, they need to prove to themselves that they CAN do it and that they ARE good enough. And that Failure does not mean the opposite. SO.... my suggestion: perhaps you could partner with some mentors and industry professionals to create opportunities for individuals to experience personal growth and help others achieve their life/career dreams. So that others don't have to experience the same difficulties in pioneering that you and I did. This doesn't have to be a full-time thing, but a branch of your channel could be a possibility (or however you see it working).

Sorry for the long read and I hope whatever you chose to do is a step in the right direction :)

TLDR - Suggestion:
perhaps you could partner with some mentors and industry professionals to create opportunities for individuals to experience personal growth and help others achieve their life/career dreams. So that others don't have to experience the same difficulties in pioneering that you and I did. This doesn't have to be a full-time thing, but a branch of your channel could be a possibility (or however you see it working).

Best regards,
Cameron

It's almost a paradox to be able to see the results of the experiment because the claim is that watching the experiment, or measuring whether the photons passed through one slit or the other, changes the interference pattern. Okay. Now that I've gotten that out of the way. The thing that has the most impact on me about photons from a philosophical view is the destiny of photons and the personal connection I have to the stars I have directly observed. A given photon may have left a given star millions or even billions of years ago, traveling through space on a solitary journey to earth. A journey that takes what is to me an eternity (and then some). It's fate, however, from the time it came into existance was to strike my eye. I literally made a physical connection to the star from which it came. It may have started before the earth was even formed, narrowly missing unknown and uncountable obstacles which could have stopped it at any time. The continents broke away and merged and broke away again. The dinosaurs rose and fell, and still it traveled. I looked up one night at just the right time to have it strike my eye, perhaps through a telescope. Billions more struck my eye which made the same journey, but each had the exact same individual destiny. The star from which they came may even be gone but the connection was made.

Hey Derek, here's an idea: why do we humans enjoy musical notes that are some specific frequencies apart? For example most birds don't sing on a scale, they're sort of untuned instruments if we look at it from a rigid musical point of view (not a musician, forgive me if I'm wrong here). I suspect it's a psychological, evolutionary result, because our fingers are naturally producing those interval frequencies on a string. We don't have music that, say, uses intervals ten times shorter than we currently have, even though a violin or a special piano may play it. (of course, it would require 10 times better finger accuracy on a violin, if it can be done at all...). I couldn't find any research on this, I thought it may be an interesting subject for you to approach. You've been giving me a lot of fun times, insight and discovery, thank you so much, we definitely need more people like you.

Interesting, my experience is the total opposite. I've been working hard on filmmaking for years and I have been doing a lot of things professionally; editing, directing, writing etc. All the opposite things to this. At the same time, I've always been interested in science, in thought, in philosophy. So I have ended up working in film, storytelling and the creative arts, but I always have this other side, auto-dictating philosophy, studying as much physics as I can with the time I have outside of film. Philanthropy - You could either go to third world countries and teach physics and maths to the kids there because the language of film is universal. People who do not know English can still understand visuals and learn a great deal. The other option is opening up a production house. You see a car is just a wagon with a motorised wheel. But it was through a series of innovations that the car has become a much more complex and useful machine. At present we can see the same evolution taking place in the Drone industry. But what about film? We know for a fact that during the studio system, there were different studios and they had different approaches to story telling. But they died down. Why? Perhaps because they did not have a powerful research team. Sadly that is the state of the affairs even now. Filmmakers are left on their own to come up with these radical ideas. There is no financial support for them. They suffer and wither and die away. I believe their are other story telling methods out there. There are other techniques available there. But somebody needs to gather these radical thinkers, these explorers and help them find these new avenues. What a great loss it is for mankind? Isn't it strange that the film industry has no research wing?

As a teacher of physics you understand the importance of energy and the conservation of it. Intelligence, opportunity, and a willingness to persist mean nothing when a person lacks the energy needed. There is a stored energy in traditional employment. As you said, there are clear paths laid out, that's energy conserved, there is stored energy in a company that writes you a paycheck and pays your insurance premiums. There is energy conservation in team work, (and some people carry more load than others.) The remarkable thing you possessed that brought you here, above an beyond your brains and your charm is an unusually high level of energy. Most people I know are too exhausted at the end of the day to have enough mental energy to even craft their own plan, never mind execute it. So this is a great pep talk, but it's really only useful to the very small portion of the population who possesses the amount of energy you do, people with energy (and money) to spare.

It's appreciated nonetheless. In much the same way people who can't travel (like me, because of my health) can enjoy travel vicariously through video, I have been able to vicariously enjoy your success. When I was young and still had (some) energy, I too very much wanted to educate people through film. (I still do.) I am happy for you that you had the opportunity to succeed, and I enjoy listening to you talk about the process. It's like a geek fairytale.

Dude, we teachers are thanking you. You found an obscure teaching method (call it teaching through failure) and I have made it a part of my teaching every day. I literally shout at them that we do not learn through success but through failure and that is the point of your videos. They have learned through your videos that we have to guess, guess WRONG and then our minds are open for a brief moment when we find ourselves to be WRONG... THAT is the moment that I strike and drive the right concept into their heads. It is much, much easier for my students to NOT TRY and then they don't have to deal with being wrong. No one wants to be wrong... but WHEN they are wrong, and they SEE they are wrong, they are truly ready to learn. I don't think you have taken this concept far enough in the teaching world and I am willing to bet that brain science will back up the idea that finding yourself to be WRONG will let you rewrite the universe in your head. I know some interesting work was done with people that thought vaccines were bad, taught the truth, and then the ones that were made to feel good about themselves actually changed, but the controls still didn't go out and get their kids vaccinated. We have to feel GOOD about learning the truth to have it stick.

We can't make them feel stupid for having wrong concepts in their heads. We need to celebrate the rewriting of their understanding. I try to do that every day. I must warn you since you are not in the classroom... They are getting what you and I would call "dumber". What I mean is they grasp the world they live in less and less. This past week, I was doing a measurement lab and I gave them a box and a ruler and told them to calculate the volume of the box. That was the precursor to calculating density (something they REALLY struggle with).

They could not tell me the volume of a box with a ruler to measure it. I said, "length, width, height" and then they would say " and what do I do with that?" I can understand not knowing EM induction (hard to get them to grasp), but not knowing that the volume of a box is the length times width times height... it boggles the mind. (these are kids from educated, well off families in a nice school district... Poverty isn't the issue here).

When I retire in about 6 years, I"m going to start a channel "crap high schoolers need to know!" The list is long and it gets longer each day.

Again, thanks for making MY job and MY life better. I can teach much better with a polished youtube video than talking and writing in front of the class. Thank you for making me a better teacher. OH and Vsauce, and smarter every day, and physics girl. My son is constantly jumping around and say "Vsauce! Michael here!". You guys have made learning vastly more available and teaching easier. I just wish we could have a VERITAS rating on videos that people could say how much truth and value videos have...

Re: trying to decide what to do with Veritasium next:

If you're looking for a change of pace that aligns more closely with parenthood — the constraints, the feelings of awe and wonder and legacy — I'd love to see more "poignant thoughts" style videos. Example: 5: 37 to 7: 00 of "Our Greatest Delusion" still gives me chills to this day, and I have that section written down in my list of favorite motivational/inspirational quotes and passages. You've got a gift for communicating complex subjects in a concise but meaningful way, and as the example above and other small moments in your videos have hinted at, I imagine that gift extends beyond science education. =)

What do I mean by "poignant thoughts" style? Come for the science, stay for the philosophy. Present a subject, explain its significance, pontificate on the profundity and deeper meaning to the human experience. Dig out some old high school or college diaries/blogs/ramblings if it helps you recall your thoughts and feelings when you first realized The Thing you're talking about. Film it in your office/studio at home between meals and naps, without any demonstrations, animations, or on-location work; the content your audience is here for lives in your brain anyway, not in the external world. Resist the The Fraud Police when they come knocking at your door to tell you no one wants this type of content that's been done many times before — I know I want it, and I think most of your audience would agree with me that your version would be in a completely different league from others' versions of this style; there's no comparison. =)

Anyway, that's my two cents. If you ever dig this deep on the comments, I hope it helps. =)

Hi Derek, I'm a former teacher who has long enjoyed (and used on students) your videos. I am at the end of some personal struggles and finding my way back to doing creative things, and I just sent an application to the Sciencium project of yours. Youtube seems biased against your videos so I only found out about Sciencium today :(

Anyway, the one thing I, as both a teacher and a learner of things, have had trouble with is the flood of unstructured knowledge. So a while back I started structuring and expanding all the knowledge I could access into one cohesive whole, inspired in part by the Big History project. I am now trying to find a way to use it. I have a nearly complete and detailed body of research that leads from The Big Bang to how cell phones show YouTube videos, down to the atomic scale of explanations. And partially inspired by your work, I have battled with philosophical questions on why anything from all that is worth learning, subject by subject, and how this knowledge reflects on the human experience. I do writing, animation, editing and all the boring stuff; I hate being the one in the limelight. I also happen to be starting up a certain movie project, but that's another matter entirely, I just thought of mentioning it because you mentioned film. Dunno why, exactly :)

Wanna do something together? As in, want me to do a lot of stuff for you and you get the glory in return for your insights on the matter? Yes, I am starved for likeminded friends, why do you ask?

Consider checking out the podcast The Hidden Brain by Shankar Vedantam.  You may recognize it if you listen to NPR.  He does some wonderful storytelling about current brain research and human behavior research.  As a child development and parenting educator, I think you (as a parent of two amazing and developing minds) might enjoy looking at the impact of Toxic Stress (hormones) on the physiology of the brain ( in both the immediate and in a developmental sense). Much of my work is with parents trying to better understand children's behaviors and thus communication.  As a result I often have marveled and wondered about what it must be like to be an 18-month-old and not understand time.  (take a moment and try to un-imagine or un-understand time)  To not know how long things will last, to only have an enate ability to recognized patterns and thus build a cognitive 'map' of what to expect next.    Who knows how well any of this will translate to this visual medium, however, you've been a great 'translator' so far.  For some old-school inspiration, try to find some old research video (from the 1970s?) about something called the perceptual cliff (which is really about the importance and power of a trusted parent's smile).  Either way, I look forward to more does of Veritasium - Thank you for all your hard work.

I actually liked the misconception videos the most, because I learned so much! I always like the videos where the video actually tries to explain something, instead of bombarding us with a ton of information with little to none explanation and context, which maybe 1% of the audience could truly understand. So naturally the video should be relatively short (~5 mins?) and try to explain a more basic concept in physics, in whatever way. They could be based on experiments, real life examples...

I suggest not turning it into a family channel. I think that's unhealthy for kids to have cameras shoved in their face 24/7 and also spending time editing all that footage when you could be with them.

I started my family 12 years ago at 26. I've never been a go-getter (depression and anxiety etc) so I regret not doing much with my life up to that point. But since I had kids, I'm confident that I'm a decent father and providing for them as best I can. When I'm not working, I'm typically doing something that involves them, or pretending like I'm pulling my weight with chores.

Enjoy the kids while they're young. If I was to make a lot of money from something like YouTube, I'd consider saving up a bunch and quit working for a few years.

Anyway, enough rambling 😀🇨🇦

This is another one of your videos which inspires, something I greatly appreciate. It isn't a blind, idealistic "you can do anything," but an intelligent "take chances." As a prospective creative, I use these videos as a motivational jumpstarter via Youtube playlist.

I do agree with your idea of not succumbing to the Survivor Bias, although I do admit that I may fall prey to it. One difference is that I have taken precautions. I, fortunately, have decided upon a career where the fail rate is high, although there are books from editors about reasons people fail. The information is public, and I have the resources to learn from their failure.

We all work and fight for satisfaction and contentment.  But satisfaction rarely becomes contentment, and that's a grace.  That keeps us going without having to question where we are going or why.  Actually achieving contentment, though, is the worst thing that can happen to someone who wants to work and fight, or who feels that they must work and fight to justify their existence.  At some point, you have to decide: is contentment something you really work and fight to achieve, or is contentment the excuse you use to justify your desire to work and fight?  If contentment is something you work and fight to achieve, you can stop working and fighting, as soon as you achieve it.  Maybe it will stay with you, with minimal maintenance, or maybe it won't.  But, if you really were working and fighting to be content, and you are content, you might as well enjoy that for as long as you can.  But, if contentment was only ever a MacGuffin to drive the plot of your hero's journey, then destroy it as soon as you get it.  Become a tragic hero-- your own worst enemy, since you've defeated all the others.  Be a fool just to prove the value of your wisdom.  Get weak just to prove your strength.  Destroy all of the value you've created in your life, so that you have hope of redemption.  You have to decide what the thesis of your life's narrative will be, and what kind of story it will be.  It does not have to be an interesting story, unless you insist that it must be.  It can be interesting at first, and then just become horribly boring.  Or, it can be horribly interesting from start to finish.  The more interesting you want it, the more tragedy you must involve in the narrative.  It's all up to you, and you are responsible only to yourself for how you live your life.  Everyone else will live their lives, too, until we are all gone like the dinosaurs, and only the birds  remain.

You know, there's a FASCINATING world of human developmental and family science. Some really incredible research. As a dad myself, it's fun to see that science happening with my kids in real time...and I'll admit that I do run some of the developmental experiments on them. :)
Some of Paiget's experiments are mind blowing and incredibly well conceived. Machine learning and AI ties into neuroscience and human development, and you can literally watch little kids going through the same stages of learning that we do with machines. John Gottman's experiments with children and emotional development are extremely practical science, and it's very rewarding to try some of his discoveries and watch them work.

Congrats on your family. I think you'll find positive and entertaining ways to combine your love of film, of science, and your family. :)

Hi man, so I don't really comment on videos, but I think this one just took my heart upto a close, and it would be a crime not to.

As you started off in the video I litrally saw my own life playing. I know how people keep asking for representation, and it truly only made sense to me today.

I was an above average student myself and was granted a scholarship for engineering in my city, in Pakistan. Although I had a passion for film making, I never took it serious as a career choice. And after completing one year, in 2012, as Malala, the noble peace laureate was attacked by the Taliban, so was I, a few months before her. It changed my life as I had to drop out of college. Long story short I took a gap year and made a couple of films, that were really a huge hit in my city and community, especially on my activism channel on YouTube. Most specifically because it was somewhat autobiographical. As it encouraged terror stricken kids to not give up on education.

After a year or reapplying, I was given an admission in one of the top Engineering universities in Pakistan. As I completed my bachelor's however, I bored out of it. I'm no longer interested in the dull chips anymore. I've graduated more than 6 months ago, and have applied for Engg jobs. But have failed to get in, in any real place.

These days I freelance as a web developer and design enthusiast now, tis video came at such an important time in my life, as I look up at career choices, every day is a struggle. Thabkyou for this. I don't even know if you'll get to read it. But thankyou so very much. :')

It feels nice to connect with someone for once. :')

Wow, Derek! That's amazing! Throughout the video, I had a constant smile on my face. I realised it when the video was finished. I have been watching your videos continuously since I don't know when (could be from ~2011). It's amazing because the photons and phonons you have recorded will be there forever as long as the human race will survive. Its amazing because of the emotions you put to analyse those zeroes and ones and expressed them wholeheartedly. Indeed, I was missing your videos but the recent non-digital accomplishments of yours bring tons of joy to us who have been constantly inspired by you. The evolution of my scientific journey and me as a human being has been nurtured by several important people. Some of them are long gone before I was even born. I had to read their equations from some bad teachers, although, later reading their papers was a delight because I knew them those bad teachers. But among a few who are of my lifetime, I am glad to hearing and seeing one of them (that's you) continuously due to YouTube. Thanks for coming to my life and introducing several various things to it. I do not believe in academic degrees. Having degrees in several completely different subjects of science, I have a strong interest in art and music on which I do not have any degrees. Similar to currency we have invented degrees to quantify our abilities which are simply not quantifiable, I believe. So, thanks for inspiring not only just me once again but also to those who are just starting their academic career. I think this is a video which must be shown to all the undergraduates in their first year. Take your time to come up with the next videos; it's alright to crawl; in fact I think the three important projects of your life which we were partly (partly because in your mosquito biting video you have already introduced your wife) unaware of also reason couple of grey hair with which you look awesome!

I have lived my fair share of disappointments when it comes to life choices. My father told me when i was growing up in his company that ''You should not make your dreams into your day job otherwise those passions will fade away''. I kind of understood what he meant but i kept my hopes and dreams very close to heart and did what i could given the circumstances as years went by. My scholarship was a failure and i ended up doing a few different menial jobs and now i look at what i do and i question my happiness. It is not here nor missing, but strangely afar. I sit back once in a while and try to recollect what those hopes and dreams had been and realise what their motivations were based on only to realise that i was limited by my imagination, knowledge, and society in so many ways, both for the worst and for the best. I feel like i'm adrift and unsure what will force me to change and improve upon next. Take care my friend and may life guide you to find what you are looking for -.-

I think you should make videos exploring the scientific method and critical thinking in general. I think the general public is well educated in some scientific concepts but we're somewhat ignorant in understanding what science is. Misinformation is absolutely everywhere and it's just impossible to debunk every single false claim we stumble upon, and even harder to reach a broad enough audience to contain the spread of false information. If people were more educated on how to think critically and how to defend themselves against false information, people wouldn't feel alienated from science and the ever-growing wave of the anti-science mindset would fade. A great book that I wish more people would read is "The Demon Haunted World" by Carl Sagan. It was written in 1995 but I feel like it's more and more relevant every day.

Hey Derek!

Awesome to see a video from you again. I am one of those college kids you mentioned, just finished film school and moved to los angeles.

I recall I sent you an email once about becoming involved with science communication, and you challanged me to write a script for an episode. This stumped me, because my strength was in visual communication, not writing. At the time, I got bummed out and gave up. However, that failure stuck with me.

My senior year of college I took a "writing for TV" class, where we were challenged to write episodes for new/existing shows. This was right around the time that Mindfield had come out, so I took the chance to try my hand at writing an episode. To my surprise I found a lot of joy in researching a topic to the fullest extent that I could, and fitting the data inside a digestible and entertaining format.

If it hadn't been for the way that you prompted me and challenged me, I might never have tried my hand at writing an episode, and learning new things along the way. So I wanted to say thank you for that.

Which brings me to my next bit: you have a strong platform and brand for science communication, something you didnt have when you were young and new to the industry. Would you consider using your platform for other passionate science communicators, where you control the quality of content, but provide those withat an audience the brand?

Another idea, is in relation to your newfound family values. Right now, Butch Hartman is launching a family entertainment network, OAXSIS, and i know for a fact the world could use a new BILL NYE equivelant. Just saying!

As a beamline scientist who works with physical beamlines (mechanics, electronics, etc.), the software that controls them, data collection and analysis, and also tour groups of all ages, one of my favorite questions is, "How do you make a straight line?"

The answers vary. Usually the first one is, "use a ruler". To that I ask, "How do you know the ruler is straight?" Honestly, there aren't many replies to that, at least not in the time available. At this point, depending on the audience, I might mention ancient Egyptian rope pullers or I might ask, "Well, what does it mean for a line to be straight?" I try to leave hints of things people might look into before I skip to what we do once the beamline components are aligned.

There are many different paths one can take with the simple question. I like the historical (pre-historical, even) in part because people don't expect it when touring a synchrotron light source. I try to connect it, however briefly, to as many things as possible: agriculture, architecture, astronomy, general relativity, lasers, roads, bridges, and even the very idea of truth itself. In at least English, we also use "true" as a verb. (Granted, "aletheia" is a different notion.) The question of what it means for a line to be straight is a way to introduce the idea of error and move beyond simple measurements.

I grew up rather poor and around drugs. My mother was together with a well meaning man, but they made terrible choices financially, and as parents. But my interest in electronics and computers forced me to go to school. After my mother split with the "well meaning man" when I was 17, she moved to another state while I dropped out of high school and started doing drugs of my own. Inside though, I wanted to be an engineer. I just have to know how the world works. I went back to school for my GED and attended a tech collage for electronics not thinking about a job or pay, but that'd I know how an amplifier works. People on my pay level and skill level have all had decent parenting, help with collage, and most of them still don't pay for their own cell phone bill (still on dads plan..). While I sit there getting to that same spot as them, with 4x as long of a road to get there, I don't feel like people with a decent up bringing understand other peoples paths in life. They tend to think everyone has that same up bringing as them. So the "follow your dreams" is only true if it's true to you.

Honestly, I could write a very, very long response to this video, so I'll try to keep it short. I really love the videos that you make, not just because it has to do with science, but because you're also quite inspirational. That sounds dumb and cheesy, but I'm genuinely motivated to do more with my life and passions simply because of you (it probably helps that you know how to edit properly and add some inspirational music at key points). I feel like I can relate to the journey that you have had. I've known since the 5th grade that Biology is my passion, but it seemed very unclear how to become the scientist that I've dreamt to be. I ended up majoring in German literature...which...is another passion of mine, but the question still exists: how am I going to get from a degree in literature to be able to surround myself with Biology and science?
It's still something I'm trying to figure out, but it seems like I am at a pivotal point in my life. I now live in Germany (I can live and breathe German everyday now instead of just in the classroom) and...I recently was accepted to a program to study Biology (in German, bless my soul). Up until now, it was a very difficult path, facing my own trials and tribulations, failure, speculation from those I've surrounded myself, etc etc...and I think I've maybe only come this far because I was (and still am) ignorant to how massive and difficult my dreams are to achieve.

I hate when people say "just follow your dreams." It's a pretentious mantra that, as you said, doesn't take into consideration how many others have failed trying to achieve the same thing...but it's simple: if you don't try, then you don't have any chance of success. Having stability is great, but I didn't want that and I knew, in the direction that I wanted to go, that stability doesn't exist (or at least not yet).

So, anyways...thank you for your awesome videos! And for clarifying misconceptions! And for educating us on science! And thank you for being the inspiration that I, and others, need(ed).

I feel the critical thinking skills you developed in engineering and physics and shared in those videos are extremely valuable in our present world where we are bombarded with information of poor quality and manipulated for effect. I think you could have a significant impact on our world by continuing to bring to light the general usefulness and importance of these critical thinking skills. I like that you have feet in both science and art. I also have this combination of interests with degrees in theatre production and chemistry. The creativity of scientific hypothesis and the engineering of experiments benefits from a creative and artistic mind. Without this artistic influence science would not grow and what is learned could not be communicated to the layperson.

What you do at Veritasium is essential to public knowledge of the frontiers of science. It make science approachable. I love that you are making time for your family even if that makes the channel develop slower. A steady, methodical approach is best in the long term. Have you looked at going the route of Grant over at King of Random and making the channel more of business rather than owning your job. Grant hired a host to make time for more projects, but I like seeing you in the videos and you are good at it. You could stay as host and producer and hire out the editing, scripting, production arrangements, etc. to a team of freelancers. This would cut into your channel profit, but it would lead to more videos with less of your time. There is a cost benefit analysis to be done.

Whatever you choose to do with the channel and your personal life, I for one will support. Keep doing what you do at whatever pace serves your life.

If the underlying reason for Veritasium is promoting evidence based truth, and if you're willing to take the risk, pulling apart misconceptions, lies and bias that impacts directly on the health and well being of society may be a direction you can take on a few videos. Focusing a light on policies and agendas that affect great numbers of people or the world could be a direction you at least, bring into the mix. There is plenty of science based policy that needs a light cast on it.
Another area is motivation. You have produced a few videos now that are motivational in, I think, a healthy way. However, there is a risk in a lot of online motivational videos that they seem to make one feel like they are 'finally' taking the right steps. But they seem to satiate the mind and when they are done, one goes right back to where they were. The video, the visualization, the music, the feeling of success is all contained in the video. Its like a drug that replaces the real thing, the reel success that comes after long hard work. Perhaps you could look into the science behind feeling satisfied and rewarded from real human interaction and the real overcoming of failure to 'finally' reach a goal.

Personally, I think we are beginning to see a shift towards more direct scientific communication. I think we are about to see entities like NASA and USGS invest in communication and education through places like YT. I think FB has permanently altered it's market share due to it's recent misgivings, and that just leaves YT. There are a handful of people that could really take something like a NASA YT channel and turn it into something much bigger than anything we can imagine. I'd like to see someone take on a challenge like this. Imagine the potential if someone had broad spectrum NASA access with the sole purpose of creating educational content. If you had the authority to pull people away for a few minutes at a time when needed, broad scale access, and an open and simple directive with open creative license, I think the potential is enormous. In my opinion, the future is science telling the science story instead of the story of science getting told through an unaffiliated third or fourth party filter. That's the kind of thing I could see you doing well at.
-Jake

Perhaps Veritasium is made up of 42 "imaginatrons", adding another "dimension" to the periodic table to avoid colliding with the real element 42? Well maybe, this is my personal theory. This reignited an idea I had, that I don't think I'm personally capable of: Modern physics for kids.

I know, there's a lot of math involved in truly understanding physics (although, I think that math education could probably be improved in a few ways for the benefit of younger kids as well), but the other big stumbling block for understanding the way the world works is the fact that things like relativity and quantum physics just don't work the way people are used to thinking about the world. It's not like humans are incapable of wrapping their minds around that sort of thing, though; I, personally, have no problem with it, and I sometimes find it difficult to deal with people who don't. (Unfortunately, I never did get that math education, so physics research isn't for me at this point in my life.) I realized, though, that kids don't have a decade or more of experience with the low-energy macroscopic world to get in the way. What exists in their imaginations is just as real as the room in which they're sitting. Little kids should be able to grasp ideas like four-dimensional spacetime and spooky action at a distance just like they pick up their parents' language or the rules of whatever obscure variant of tag their neighborhood tends to play.

So, there's my idea. Something about teaching physics like you have been for all this time, and something for your kids, and for others. I'm not that great on child development beyond language learning models, so you'd probably have to do some research on what age ranges and how to present to them, but in a nutshell, physics for kids.

Hi Derek! As a 12 year high school physics teacher in Burlington Ontario I thank you sincerely for your work! I’ve showed your “World’s Roundest Object” video every year to my IB students to intro the SI system as well as your combined video with Minute Physics dealing with magnetism!  I think you could do a lot of good by making the hardest high school concepts more easily understandable to the students. Topics like the black body spectrum (especially its dependence on discrete mathematics), the reason that some materials are transparent to different wavelengths of EM radiation, field theory vs Feynman diagrams etc etc... you are a great guy and I wish you lots of success in the future!

After nothing but playing guitar and writing music for eight years, and in the end with my band dissolving, I gave up on trying hoist myself up the slippery slope of the music industry; perhaps my dreams were greater than my age. Now within two years I've gone from below basic algebra to calc II, and I'm keen on teaching myself a bit of linear algebra and multi-variable calc before next semester. I never considered myself a math or science "person", mainly because it was "cool" to be dumb where I went to grade school, but I tried because I needed to see what I was capable of; now I'm not looking back. Thanks Veritasium, Derek and your family, for being one of the catalysts that got me invested in my education, and for showing us all how fun it is to learn. You've already left an impact.

You asked for ideas. I am frustrated by the way that media influences people's decisions when they broadcast poor research. To really make a decision based on research, you're probably aware about selecting the right population and making that match what you're looking at, etc. I wish there was something that the public had access to (like your channel) that constantly focused on squashing the misinformation from poorly portrayed/done research. Like a Snopes for research-driven changes that may be very beneficial or very harmful if carried out by the general public without adequate understanding of the how to apply primary research.  An example of this would be the research "findings" that were released about vaccines and autism (I'm not trying to argue one way or the other here, just using the verified facts from that incident as an example). If there was a source that people could look to to explain the main research that was released and find out that it was totally unreliable and biased and influenced by personal financial benefit before it was released I feel like we wouldn't be fighting the dangerous anti-vaccine movement that we are today. You are the type of person I could see combating misinformation like this.

Things I would like to see is application of what was learned over the years into the new unknowns.
How to take what you learned over the years, life experience, mistakes, successes etc, and now that you have a family and have hit that peak or near peak point.
How it can be turned around to find out what you want to do, or ideas to change the way of thinking in the field.

EG. I am a sr validation engineer (which is a long name to say I validate something works in an automated setting and have experience).
The areas I am wanting to work on has to do with the unknowns of food production and automation in the light of climate change (whether you believe it was man made, or hoax, or whatever it still exists to an extent).
So I am having to take my years of knowledge in hardware, technology and software. Then learn the stuff I don't know well (agriculture), and pool then into a cohesive plan which I don't have atm.

I didn't become a software tester, dev, PM, or other avenues I have ended up down. I originally wanted to be a chef, while I am good at cooking I have also moved on from that interest.
Due to my place in tech though I know the old fashioned method of growing food in giant fields in the desert is a very inefficient way to do things, cannot handle weather changes well, and most of the food comes from areas that have little to know water due to ideal weather conditions.
So I want to take what I have learned and figure out how to do something different that is exciting. While I enjoy what I do, I have also been doing it for 20-30 years, as it was never my goal for a future I am wanting to use my still sharp mind to find what I want to do when I grow up, before I lose my sharpness.

I think the concept you touch on at 9:45 is related to the concept of "proactive serendipity" that Simon Clark talks about in a recent video of his: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rsFk8SKYSDg
The gist is that not all hard work alway leads to success but the hard work puts you in a position where -- with a little bit (or a lot) of luck -- you might just be successful and achieve your goals. However, if you don't put in the work you also won't ever be in the position where you can experience that kind of luck that pushes you towards success.

The only issue I have is that what I want to do that is statistically biased towards failure is partly so because I don't know enough about that field and don't know where to go to learn more. The issue here is that the methods of learning more in business and engineering are not exactly what I feel I'm comfortable with? What I mean is how some people are practical learners, others can absorb information by reading about it. It was only a level two engineering course but some aspects of course work didn't particularly appeal to me, specifically some coursework that required researching materials to make a bracket out of, the requirement to use paper based resources then computer based resources to back up the choice of material made from the paper based resources. From what I've found out about a business course, it would be something similar, only it would be visiting a business, taking notes about it's different aspects, eg. marketing etc, and creating documents talking about it. These are things that I'm not comfortable with and why I've reached a point where I don't know what to do as a next step.
Oh, and it requires a huge amount of money with the potential to not be the most profitable in the current market of the UK (where I am). :(
3 things I'd like to achieve (but are very much daydreaming at the moment) are;
1. Have my own business which builds and installs gates for driveway with a different design and operation to some I've seen around. (Boring, I know).
2. Have a garage business with a large area of private property to have an area where car enthusiasts can enjoy their cars without being a nuisance on public roads.
3. Have a biofuel production company, international, with an idea that I've seen on YouTube (I'd try and have a partnership with those who came up with the idea, not steal it) so that a renewable energy source can be produced in the quantity required to run everything that currently runs off fossil fuels so that the infrastructure currently in place can continue to be used, without having to convert every aspect of it to electric, therefore saving the country a lot of money, I'd assume in the millions at least. I don't know the exact values but if every car in the UK was to be swapped for an electric one and the average annual mileage was covered by them all, I calculated (very roughly) that the country's electricity production would need to almost double. I would assume that the installation of offshore wind farms would be in the millions, not including the cost of the hundreds of thousands of public charging points needed for all spaces in public car parks and on street parking, and all of this is just for cars. If the quantity of biofuel can be produced to fuel all of today's technology to power tomorrow's world. Also save the combustion engined cars (petrolhead things).

I can feel a similarity in my life here.

I have a successful career writing and designing software. I got into it through sorta not being smart enough to realize I couldn't write software, stumbling through my mistakes until eventually I became fairly decent at it. I did what I enjoy doing, or at least half of what I enjoy... because unlike you, I never figured out how to take my other love and combine it with my software engineering.

I studied music in college. I performed music for much of my early adulthood. I've played a solo euphonium part for the emperor of Japan with that nation watching me at Budokan. I performed tight vocal harmonies in counterpoint with a madrigal group in various churches in England for a week. And I could sight-read most of the music set in front of me as a consequence of my training in the military and college.

But I never figured out how to combine these well.

Fortunately, I do enjoy writing software, and people seem willing to pay me to do it, so I'm okay. Personal computers didn't exist when I was a child. We only had kinda crappy 8-bit machines that weren't very capable during my teens, but I worked with them anyway, because they were interesting. Now, I work with machines that communicate together in a weird dance, some of whom are real, some of whom are virtual, making these things think a bit for us, so we can focus our thoughts on other matters.

Always Be careful of that survivorship bias.

Build yourself a decent safety net, an try stuff. But don't rely on that to work out.

What's the relationship between engineering and film? Lots, if you ask me. The question is whether or not people in the industries agree with me. My experiences as a "range rat" have lead me to believe that I've seen a little bit about the technical aspects of filming...just in a different venue. You don't want to lose light, you want to predict conditions where you're running some sort of test (often with very little "ground truth" to work with, but some research nonetheless), and you're hoping to do what is needed with the equipment to get fairly good results. Remember films like the Matrix and every other "innovative" special effects blockuster that's every been? The more you know about natural light sources in a variety of bands, atmospheric scattering, BRDF, camera/sensor internals, heat transfer, vegetation/minerals, the better. What do you know about computational photography? Seems like field a lot of industries are interested in.

My first thought was, "I did not like this video." When I thought about why, I realized it was too similar to my own story, except that you tried a lot harder before "giving in" to become an engineer/science person.

When I was in college, I loved computer graphics. To give you an idea of when that was, SGI was still a thing, Jurassic Park (the original one) had not yet come out, but I had access to a lot of computers and a few high-end SGIs with the "reality engine" installed. I wrote raytracing systems (this was long before the common ones existed), experimented with ways to make them more photorealistic, and read every SIGGraph paper I could lay my hands on. I lacked one thing, something people call "creative talent."

I could make a re-creation of a scene, either real or from a cartoon, but I could not make the original design in ways others found appealing. I tried to make a few short movies, similar to the ones found on the brand-new-then "Mind's Eye" videos. I managed to make a few, but not many, and people though they were interesting but not great.

I was already a strong coder, and loved science in almost every way, at least the physical sciences. Engineering was an easy path for me.

I've come to realize that I hate the "creative" vs "engineering" side of things. Writing code is creative, it's just not what movie creators call "creative." It's taken some years to realize I'm just as creative as someone who directs a movie, with a lot less support staff.

I did not get a vocational education from my school as the last 3 years was a basic engineering education for preparation of the swedish version of college. I did military training for 11 months after school and then into work life. After doing a little of what was needed wherever i got into a short time vocational education in automation engineering which i almost finished. I got a job in the field of service and support for a company that works with systems used on commercial cargo ships and then it went on for a few years. The company had to cut down and I got fired. After a while of doing a little here and there for local companies, i took a job of taking care of people with demensia for a year to get some stability. This ended and I got into doing development and maintaining a website and webmail for a medium sized site. It was a struggle every month and when i got asked to do an installation on a ship for an automation system, i quickly said yes. This resulted in me doing retrofit of automation systems on LNG carriers for 10 years before i got tired of being away from my family so much and had to make a drastical change. I quit and then our main supplier, Siemens, called med and told me to call a number. I called them and got employed even as they were not looking for personnel in the area i lived. As the company is a partner with Siemens in many areas, i could continue work with Siemens software and do a lot of work with developing them. The experience i have gotten doing my job have made me one of the most experienced in Scandinavia with Siemens SIMIT, PCS7 and COMOS as with the integration of these softwares to build a digital representation of plants and factories.

I am just a grunt. Think what you can do with hard work and being interested in your work as well as always pushing your barriers to learn yourself new things.

Loved this video.

But what I took away from this video was NOT "Chase your dream, try it at least once. Better to try and fail than to fail without trying". Instead the lesson I took away from your story was, "Get yourself right. Establish a firm foundation, find yourself, set yourself up for success, and THEN follow your dreams." I think your story is becoming true for many of us, and will continue to grow even more true. Our world is becoming more stable, and giving us the opportunity to branch out more and more. With time people will find the freedom to unite their otherwise disparate passions to create entirely new fields. Why not combine filmmaking and engineering or physics? Why not choreography and history, or chemistry and cooking? In my case, it's computer science and psychology.

Most of us have multiple interests which don't inherently align, but absolutely could. We just finally have the freedom to stop specializing entirely and to have an easier, safer time mixing our passions together.

I have to thank people like you, the Green Brothers, Tom Scott, the guys over at Vsauce, Brady at Numberphile/Computerphile, Matt Parker, CGPGray, Henry at Minutephysics and Destin on Smarter Everyday for making your channels. You guys having this drive to combine filmmaking, education and your passions have led to many of us learning so much, not just about the world, but the people in it.

How they grow up resentful and have trust issues? I now suffer for my complete and utter disdain for even the smallest white lie. Can't keep a job; I'm currently unemployed. Relationships don't typically last. Therapy doesn't work and meds made me paranoid. Drug use made me a criminal (clean now; seems like a small win.)
The survivorship bias applies here, because I subscribed to your channel too. No one knows who I am, but you gain something still. I'm 30 now and still seek the means to be an aeronautical engineer. Hi Derek! I doubt that you will read this comment but I'll still give it a shot, If you do hopefully it makes you smile. Ever since I discovered you on YouTube, a certain passion emerged within myself. I have always been a curious kid, but as we all grow up that "child curiosity" tends to fade away. At one point I felt that it was fading away but you saved me from a life rather empty, a life without science, wonder and amazement. Through you I discovered a world of science and the scientific community of YouTube, it changed me. From the narrow minded bullied kid I was, on a small Island in the Indian Ocean, I became so passionate about the world around me to a point that I wanted something more from life. I took my future between my hands, it was set, I was to be a scientist. I worked really hard and managed to obtain a scholarship in Australia, to study Molecular Genetics and Biotechnology. So many different fields interested me but as you know choices need to be made. I am hopefully leaning towards a PhD and hope to merge Robotics with my field of knowledge in the future.

Thank you so much again for changing my life!!
~ A kid in a wonderful world.

P.S: I can't wait to see you the 30th of July in Perth for your talk on Vitamania! As a student I won't be able to meet and greet you, hopefully in the future I will :)

I believe thanks, and congratulations are in order. So, thank you for blazing a new trail when only offered traditional ones - I believe history will bear out that early YouTubers be put beside innovators like Charlie Chaplin and George Méliès with film, or Milton J. Cross and Graham McNamee with radio. You have created something with lasting impact, that will leave this world a better place than it was when you were born into it.

Congratulations on balancing family life with your career goals. I know how difficult that can be - in fact, it can be among the most difficult feats to achieve in any life. So, well done, there.

Finally, regardless of where you were born or your family was from, thanks for admitting you are a Vancouverite. It is inspiring to see success from people from our neck of the woods.

May you continue to have success as you grow and continue whatever trail you wish to blaze from this point forward.

This is surprisingly relevant to me. I planned to only major in Computer science, but I really didn't like it all that much, so I decided to minor in what I love: Physics. After a year of taking classes for the minor and finishing all of my physics classes with a 4.0, I decided I wanted to do more, so I joined a research group on gravitational waves. I just came back last week from the International Pulsar Timing Array student workshop and had an amazing time. Among the many things that it taught me is how much I love working in physics, so I talked with a my parents and an advisor and am now double majoring in CS and Physics.

TY for doing what you love. I grew up strangely. I love learning and sharing what I have learned. Those around me were not enamored with me. My older sister and the neighborhood girls used to include me in their play and then soon I found my self all alone. What was happening was my sister was required to be engaged in play with me for a minimum amount of time. She and her friends met the requirement after which they would go away and hide from me.
I was born in 1955 and many things known to medical science today was not known then. I would learn 45 years later, I was born with a condition now called Asperger’s syndrome. I do not read faces and thus did not understand social cues. I did not understand I overwhelmed my sister and her friends.
As an adult after I had achieved my MD and finished my Psychiatric residency, I had a conversation with my older sister about these events of our childhood did I learn why she and the others fled me. My sister said it was like interacting with a 7 yo who was going on 23 yo. I constantly sounded like an adult.
The problem was it led me to being even less socialized. But my mother was aware of my difficulties and tried different things to guide me. The first of which was to hold my head in a position during a conversation and explain I must make eye contact while engaged in the conversation. This non eye contact is one of the things quite common about this neurological syndrome. Later she insisted I take the speech classes that high school offered. I then added as much communication courses I could in College. I was one course short of a Minor in Communications when I was graduated with my BS Chemistry (honors) degree. (I went on to medical school so I did not finish the Minor).
I had tools to use to do the job as a Psychiatrist.
Your YouTube channel helped me in my time of need. In 2005, I experienced bacterial meningitis with two strokes. This led to my forced retirement. You Dr Mueller provided my kind of entertainment. At home, away from the job I had made for myself was really not what I had planned for my 50’s.
You have brought joy to my life doing what you love.

Dear Veritasium/Derek. Now i encounter myself in a situation that you already know, as i write this comment i'm waiting with my wife the arrival of our baby, in his last week in the womb, so we are a little anxious but at the same time in a static happiness that is to receive another human being that has become from the decisions and actions you have taken. To me, that fact that you haven't uploaded something doesn't bother me much, i use this platform to learn or enjoy things that people have dedicated time and energy to explain, in a way that maybe the same Richard Feynman did it, in a fun and constructive way, for the sake and the pleasure of knowing things. But you know that this pleasure is not only that, and in science there is a bigger reward maybe, not in terms of money, but in a deep sense of awe. That's incredible that we can share along the world, but i think that maybe there are somethings that needs to be understood in their context, specially in their historical and sociological context, why there is a revolution in content aimed to science and people wanting to know. This is the first time I've seen you the day of posting a video. Now I know how much grey you have in your beard! Very distinguishing, by the way. This is a weak idea, but here goes...

When I was in high school (back in 1986-1991), I remember I accidentally cut my old Walkman headphone wires. I also happened to be taking electronics, so it was nothing to splice the two wires back together, and they worked good as new. However, I cut the wires again later on in those years. For some reason, the splicing didn't work. I did notice a coating on the wires. (Copper wires aren't supposed to be green.) But this is where it gets interesting... I removed the coating from the tips of the ends of the wires by sanding them down, tried splicing them again, but the headphones still wouldn't work! I also noticed some clear, very thin, fibrous strands that ran the length of the wire, but while fiber optics were certainly being looked at for electronic uses, I'm (somewhat sure?) that they weren't yet practical for stereo headphones. So, what happened? And what were those thin strands, if not fiber optics?

Till last year, when I was in 11th grade, I had no idea I would have in any form a liking for physics. By the end of 2016, I came across Veritasium and Diana from physics girl. I binge watched your videos, then discovered more amazing channels like vsauce, and that's it, I realised I had fallen in love with physics like never before and wanted to pursue a career in it. By the time I told my parents about my passion for physics, I was in the 12th grade. Telling them that I wanted to do research in physics when not once in the past I had mentioned about physics before (I just genuinely liked science, but not physics in particular) was kind of a shocker to them, but they relented. Now, after giving my 12th grade just 3 months ago, I am gonna go to uni for a physics degree. I chose my career, my passion by mere 1 years of watching youtube videos on physics, sounds crazy... But people around me have seen the love I share for physics and hence approve too.

Purpose of this message is to tell you how much of a big change this channel has brought in my life. Don't know what I would have applied for in uni, what I would have done in life if it weren't for youtube and your videos to make me realise that all along I just was passionate about physics, hidden in every single thing that I loved and was curious about.
If I ever get asked for what inspired me to be a physicist (if I ever do any breakthrough research lol), the answer is gonna be you, Diana and Micheal.

Derek I think you're a great platform for us science teachers out there who are trying to reach their students. There isn't enough content in the world that shows the process from misconception, through experimentation, into discovery, and then (critically) REVISING YOUR STANCE to account for the new information. Critical thinking is at an all time low in this modern era and I think the emphasis on the process of critical thinking, particularly the acceptance of being wrong and the willingness to change one's views, is of the utmost importance right now. Keep fighting the good fight, and help us build a better tomorrow for your children and children all over!

To put your point about survivor bias in another way: trying alone may not be sufficient for success (by a highly likely margin), but it's almost certainly necessary.

Also, while I firmly believe arts as a whole can shed light on truth in wholly unique ways, and that film can be a medium to see "reality" as it were, I don't agree that you can't lie with film. Edits, pacing, lighting, framing... all sorts of factors can show something that isn't "truth" -- and videos like your "2, 4, 8" one can at least show how to start looking. :)

I've also learnt so much about how I conduct myself from your philosophical videos, such as Learned Helplessness and Self Efficacy. I wish I could listen to more of your input on these aspects of life, but I understand it is difficult to produce all different kinds of content while supporting your family and doing all the other things you do behind the scenes.

Looking forward to the future of Veritasium!

Hearing successful youtubers talk about how all you need to do is try, is depressing, because it feels like they assume you haven't yet.

I understand it's an important message, and for those who are on the fence or didn't even think something like this was in their grasp, it might be exactly what they needed to hear.

But for the mountain of people who have tried and failed, because their content wasn't good enough, or their demographic was too niche, or they weren't charismatic enough, or any of the myriad of obstacles that aren't all able to be hurdled by everyone, it just feels like a reminder of those brick walls.

The saying goes, "if at first you don't succeed, try, try, try again". But there comes a point in reality where trying again or moving on to something else is the same decision as the one that puts food on your plate.

That being said, we all wish you luck in whatever you pursue, whether it's more Veritasium videos, documentaries like you've done in the past, or a more traditional education field.

I know you’ll probably never read this but I wanted to thank you for all you’ve done for me.

When you mentioned how your earlier videos were poor I recoiled in disagreement. Those videos were a part of what made me who I am today. They instilled in me a love for the scientific process, which I carry with me every day. They changed how I see the world in a way even I probably can’t comprehend because I can’t take off the lenses through which I see the world.

Although I didn’t take a path in physics, choosing medicine instead because it fit my calm personality and love for 1-on-1 interactions where I help people like tutoring (I could never vlog), your videos shaped my scientific mind.

Thank you, and I wish the best for your family and your 2 cute kids :)

P.S. the video type I like the most on your channel are the ones that cover great overarching concepts and problems. Although I fell in love with the experiment and interview videos that defined your channel, I think at this stage, videos like “is most published research wrong” and “what is not random” fit you and your audience better (although unfortunately YouTube doesn’t reward them like they used to, as you mentioned in your quality vs quantity video on your second channel ;)
